item.title: The Isolation 6
item.description:
Work stuff

David, our lead developer, gave me an overview of the technical architecture for GOV.UK Pay, which is really handy. It‚Äôs such an interesting platform, really makes it easy for teams and organisations to start taking payments (in 60 seconds flat!).

Tuesday was spent preparing a session to work out some strategic problems and plot some possibilities for overcoming those barriers, using techniques I learned in the IDEO course. And, you know what, I even started to enjoy my job again.

Yeah, it‚Äôs sad to admit it, but I really lost the spark and enthusiasm for my job in September last year. I used to jump out of bed in the morning, ready for the day, as dorky as that sounds. So I‚Äôm glad that feeling is starting to come back!

We‚Äôre using the North Star framework put together by John Cutler at Amplitude. Our North Star is ‚ÄòNumber of healthy integrations‚Äô which is a clear measure and aims for sustainable growth. The KPIs that make up the North Star are good too, decent key results for the teams for focus on.

Not-work stuff

Finished reading Ghost Hardware, though it is quite short. Three chapters, distinctly 2011 in feeling: a raid on a sports shop organised over social media, digital art, and toxic wastelands. Heading back to start Count Zero now.

Played our first game of Fate, the first tabletop RPG I‚Äôve ever played, and it was great! Took a few turns to get into the swing of things, to realise that we could lead the story as much as the gamemaster, but it‚Äôs super fun. Can‚Äôt believe we didn‚Äôt play this at uni when we were studying creative writing!

item.title: The Isolation 5
item.description:
Work stuff

Got started on GOV.UK Pay this week. I met the teams and started settling into life as a product manager on the Government-as-a-Platform (GaaP) programme. Already I can see how much I‚Äôm going to enjoy it! Everyone‚Äôs really skilled and passionate about the product, which makes it easier, and they‚Äôve put considerable effort into making everything understandable.

At first, I thought it would be tough engaging with the new team. You can‚Äôt rely on body language or sitting next to people, so you lose half the soft skills we frequently rely on in product management. But it hasn‚Äôt mattered one bit. I‚Äôve found that 30-minute video calls have been polite and intimate, and I‚Äôve had to focus on clear language.

One thing that really helped me start getting my feet under the table was the product manager induction Trello board that Ross created a couple of years ago. I iterated it slightly, which made it a little more effective so I‚Äôll write a blog post about that.

I‚Äôm working on two teams: one focusing on migrating to Platform as a Service, and a kaizen team focusing on continually improving the product and our processes. For strategy work, I‚Äôm looking at Direct Debits.

Next week we‚Äôll try some team sessions, to gather people‚Äôs thoughts and collaborate on setting objectives. It‚Äôll be different, for sure, but with a conch system and jamboards, I reckon we‚Äôll be fine.

Wednesday‚Äôs Show & Tell was so good, packed with really excellent work. Thinking back, I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd ever read a weeknote from Pay, so I asked if we could put one together. It‚Äôs really important that GaaP products and their successes stay on the executive team‚Äôs radar, so that solving common problems across government remains the strategy.

My notebook is packed full of scribblings that I need to turn into sensible notes or things to do. Probably need to take a few hours on Sunday to work through it.

TfL and the BBC have released some virtual backgrounds for your Zoom calls, scenes on London transport and empty sets from TV shows. It‚Äôs a really neat touch from the public service orgs. I wondered what a GDS virtual background might be: maybe just a bunch of Post-its on the wall of some hallowed Cabinet Office room.

The contact tracing app has got everyone talking about privacy, interoperability and centralised vs decentralised data models, which is really good. Apple and Google proposed and built decentralised models distinctly because they‚Äôve been criticised for their approach to privacy before, and I‚Äôm surprised that the government doesn‚Äôt just follow the tech giants ‚Äì they‚Äôve got way more resources to test these approaches out. So it makes me angry to read that money is being spent on creating a second contact tracing app with a decentralised model, ‚Äòin case politicians decide to make a switch‚Äô. 1

Although it looks like some of the data permissions patterns are being figured out by NHS rather than GDS, which is good to see.

Not-work stuff

Our world and the characters we‚Äôre creating in our Fate Core game are coming along really well, and I think we‚Äôll play our first session this weekend. Perhaps predictably, we‚Äôve come up with a dystopian cyberpunk future world with a hacker, a cybernetic prosthetics engineer and a cargo ship pilot. Who cares though, it‚Äôs just a bit of fun! Looking forward to hanging out in Axiom more often.

After finishing Microserfs, I bought Count Zero by William Gibson, the sequel to_Neuromancer_. Although I had to stop reading it two chapters in because my pre-order of Ghost Hardware by Tim Maugham came through. So after a brief stint in Bristol, suffused with sub-bass, I‚Äôll return to New Delhi.

I picked up some gems on Bandcamp Day, buying some of the albums I liked most from last year. Soundbwoy Killah, Overmono, Skee Mask, Smith & Mighty and Lee Gamble all got some ¬£¬£¬£s. Bandcamp is one of the best ways to support the musicians you love, and right now the scene needs saving. Why not buy a record or two?

Our cat loves watching the swallows fly around in the morning. I‚Äôve taken to watching them with him. Much better than watching the buses go to bed at New Cross bus garage.

They reckon No. 10 will announce changes to the lockdown on Sunday, although it‚Äôs worth mentioning that the changes will possibly only apply in England. I‚Äôm worried that the country will misinterpret the message or only hear what they want to hear, meaning the R number could rise over the next two to three weeks. So we‚Äôll stay in Wales for the rest of May. EDIT: About 2 hours after I wrote this, the First Minister extended the lockdown by 3 weeks anyway.

Started learning Welsh on Wednesday, so that‚Äôs convenient.

item.title: The Isolation 4
item.description:
These notes cover a few weeks, rather than one week like usual. Writing weeknotes in the pandemic just didn‚Äôt feel necessary over the last few weeks, getting my head out of work was a higher priority. Having said that, there‚Äôs a few things worth noting from the last five weeks of lockdown.

Things I learned working on end-to-end services

I‚Äôve spent 6 weeks working on the extremely vulnerable people service, a cross-government effort to get food and support to people with a specific medical condition or who have been told to ‚Äòshield‚Äô by their GP. When the service is successful, pockets of the country will stay at home, therefore reducing the number of people who are likely to be infected, are likely to need hospital attention, and are likely to spread the virus.

The extremely vulnerable people service is an end-to-end service delivered by multiple departments and a few third-party organisations. For those that don‚Äôt know, end-to-end services begin from the point where the user starts trying to achieve a goal to the point when they‚Äôre finished. This includes website content, the transactional part of the service, the phone, post and face-to-face channels, as well as the digital elements. And it includes the internal processes that government needs to deliver an outcome.

Here‚Äôs a few things we noticed would be helpful in building and iterating those kinds of services.

  • Progress ‚Äì even if it‚Äôs not perfect ‚Äì is better than stasis
  • Build consensus for solutions with evidence, and reduce risk together
  • Define success criteria early: how you‚Äôll know if you‚Äôre meeting users‚Äô needs or not
  • Outcomes are the glue that hold departments together
  • A shared understanding of the problem is ideal, but shared sympathy for the impact is better
  • A shared backlog makes interoperability possible for teams from different organisations
  • Test the service, end-to-end, with a small group and iterate as it grows
  • Operations and logistics processes are harder to change than websites
  • Users sometimes don‚Äôt read things, so you can‚Äôt fix failure demand with a content change
  • Speak up if you‚Äôre having a hard time, because someone else probably is too

Other work stuff

After two-and-a-bit years working on GOV.UK, I‚Äôm moving over to work on GOV.UK Pay and I‚Äôm super excited. After picking out a few skills to work on in my end-of-year conversation about professional development, it seems like GOV.UK Pay will be a really good place to double-down on user focus, strategic ownership and financial ownership.

The GOV.UK product managers gave me a lovely send-off and Martin put together a Jamboard where people could share memories of working with me. It was really thoughtful and touching, I‚Äôm going to miss them lots. Being remote means there‚Äôs less chance of catching people in the hallway, so I must remember to drop in on them occasionally.

Alex and I met with the Head of Comms to chat about weeknotes. They‚Äôre supportive of people writing about work provided they follow the Civil Service Code and don‚Äôt use personal channels as government outlets. That‚Äôs fair enough really. Anyway, they gave both our blogs the thumbs-up and said we neutered things well, so I‚Äôll share the principles I follow.

When we wound-down the personalisation work, we wanted to focus on design principles for privacy, transparency and re-use of data. It would help make the personalisation proposition understandable, accountable and trustable for users. We were going to use primary and secondary research as a method for finding the edges. No one across government is looking at this (as far as we know) and as GOV.UK is the platform in the centre, we‚Äôre best-placed to represent users across the board. I‚Äôm looking forward to seeing someone pick up the baton and run with that.

The last 8 years of transforming public services digitally has been about the interaction between citizen and state, but ‚Äòpersonalising‚Äô that means we need to invest in the conversation between citizen and state too. That‚Äôs how you make it feel personalised. That‚Äôs where the innovation lies. Create boring magic, not shiny things.

‚ÄòPublic services, funded by public money, must be open to public scrutiny ‚Äì especially in times of great upheaval when lots of decisions are being made very quickly.‚Äô Rachel Coldicutt1

Not-work stuff

Being quarantined for long periods of time hasn‚Äôt bothered me much. I was hyper-online as a teenager, spending most evenings and weekends cooped-up in my bedroom on the computer. Coding websites, surfing the web, hacking, playing Counter-Strike. Sedentary and isolated. And now it‚Äôs mandated by the government! (Shout-out to all the parents merging home life with work life, though.)

I wrote a secret post and, as far as I know, no one read it. üëã to the three people who read my second secret post.

Zoom pub quizzes are quite good, aren‚Äôt they? Highlights included bonus points when Danny Dyer popped up randomly, a sound clash, and imitating famous paintings. Actually, Zoom pub quizzes might be better than pub quizzes‚Ä¶though I do miss the pub.

Read Microserfs by Doug Coupland, which Matt recommended to me. First thought: wow, working in tech hasn‚Äôt changed much, has it?! It‚Äôs an enjoyable postmodern read, focusing on the growth of the characters as they transition from introverted code-monkeys to fully featured personalities. The comparison between Apple and Microsoft cultures was funny too, you could write that book now and make it about GDS and NHS X.

Carried on playing old PlayStation games. Tomb Raider is really quite good.

In other gaming news, I‚Äôm starting a Fate Core RPG with my best mates. I‚Äôve never played a tabletop RPG before, I figured they all involved fantasy in some shape or form, but Fate allows you to design the world and characters any way you want. As two of the crew are in Montreal and Vancouver, the rest of us in Britain, we‚Äôre using Discord for text and voice chat. I might start writing notes on our games like Michael does.

We‚Äôve spent the last five weeks living in North Wales, helping my partner‚Äôs brother deliver food and supplies to elderly and infirm relatives. We‚Äôve spent the entire time physically distancing from family, making sure that if any of us became infected we wouldn‚Äôt transmit it to each other.

It has given us a chance to road-test living here, as I don‚Äôt want to be in London for ever and it‚Äôs closer to my parents than Bristol or Cardiff. I‚Äôve always wanted to live in Wales, ever since I was a boy, as we holidayed in Llandudno most years. I think we could make it work, as long as remote working will become part of the new normal.

We‚Äôve been supporting to local economy wherever possible, buying excess beer from Cwrw Ll≈∑n, coffee from Poblado, vegetables and eggs from Treddafydd, pizza from Crust, cakes from Two Islands, fish from Pysgod Ll≈∑n and meat from the cigyddion. It‚Äôs been a delicious two weeks, the produce here is excellent. Though I do miss hauling seasonal produce back home from Brockley Market each week.

Worth saying though: we‚Äôre really privileged to be here and others don‚Äôt have this opportunity. So I‚Äôm taking nothing for granted. I hope you and your loved ones pull through this weird time.

item.title: The Isolation 3
item.description:
Work stuff

  • This week I‚Äôve been working with an incredible team of people, who spent an entire weekend building a service to deliver food to people who need it most during the coronavirus pandemic. It‚Äôs part of shielding.
  • Even though they spent long hours spinning up a service that would have otherwise taken weeks to design and build (including the logistics side), everyone put their back into ensuring the service was reliable, available and meeting user needs all week.
  • And when user feedback started flooding in (over 10,000 items in 4 days), they reviewed it and spotted an opportunity to pivot to solving a whole problem. I work with some fucking heroes.
  • It‚Äôs my job to be the shit umbrella, giving them the space to do that. So this week has mostly been about stakeholder management, concise communication, joining the organisational dots, and pitching in on performance analysis and user support.
  • We‚Äôve learned a lot ‚Äì as I‚Äôm sure many people have ‚Äì about what happens when the nucleus of work is distributed, what happens when the senior responsible owner is a network not an individual, and what viable systems of organisation in joined-up digital government might be.
  • It‚Äôs probably a good time to check notes on scaling agile.

Not-work stuff

  • Yesterday I left the house for the first time in two weeks. We went to Sainsbury‚Äôs for supplies and it was very weird. Some shelves were empty, products I hadn‚Äôt seen before replaced the usual brands, and the tannoy kept addressing us to take only three of any item. It felt like the apocalypse was happening slowly ‚Äì which it is, of course.
  • Anyway, I haven‚Äôt really done anything this week except work. Downtime has been watching telly or reading, which isn‚Äôt sustainable.
  • Oh wait, I did defrost the freezer for something to do. And started a sourdough culture, like everyone else.
  • I‚Äôd like to write about coronavirus‚Äôs effect on the food supply chain. It feels like there could be a tipping point soon, where it‚Äôs more viable for supermarkets to meet home-delivery demand by sourcing local suppliers. Not only will international suppliers become more expensive, their output will likely drop too, pushing prices up and making local suppliers more competitive. But even Farmdrop is operating at capacity.
  • We had a Zoom birthday party for a friend. It felt like being inside and outside Hogarth‚Äôs Britain, simultaneously being involved in and observing each painting all at once.
  • Going to play more Metal Gear Solid this weekend.
  • I was getting sad about not being able to eat wild garlic this year, but we managed to pilfer a hefty bag of the stuff for dinner. CAN‚ÄôT WAIT!

item.title: The Isolation 2
item.description:
Work-related notes have returned! That should excite some of you.

Uncommon times we‚Äôre living in, but extraordinary efforts are being undertaken. Shout-out to all the public service heroes working on coronavirus projects.

Work stuff

  • Missions have been paused so that we can work on urgent projects related to coronavirus. My colleagues have already delivered some excellent products and services, all delivered quickly to an emerging need. You can see most of them at www.gov.uk/coronavirus (which is very good in itself).
  • I‚Äôve been lending support to Public Health England and NHSX on a new version of their public-facing dashboard and open data tracking coronavirus in the UK. They‚Äôve created some national indicators in a very short space of time which deserves credit. But as with all statistics, there‚Äôs so much going on behind the scenes to ensure the numbers are up-to-date, accurate, and reliable. It makes your head spin to think of it all.
  • I‚Äôve been using much of the knowledge on statistics and data I picked up at Porism working on LG Inform and LG Inform Plus, which has helped me get up-to-speed on things.
  • However, it‚Äôs a v-team effort with team members distributed across different organisations with different priorities, so I‚Äôve found it tough being their delivery manager who‚Äôs not close to the decision-makers and senior stakeholders. It has really made me think about how much we take agile ways of working for granted at GDS ‚Äì encouraging others to work that way and see the value is so tough.
  • And while I was typing these notes, I was asked to start working on something else, so I‚Äôm switching back into product mode‚Ä¶NOW!
  • Any spare time I had from coordinating the dashboard team was used to work on the strategy course I‚Äôm doing through IDEO U, which I‚Äôm still loving. I‚Äôd like to apply what I‚Äôm learning to GOV.UK‚Äôs current and future strategies, but we‚Äôre hiring a Strategy Lead so it‚Äôs possibly not considered a product responsibility any more.

Not-work stuff

  • Reinstalled Retropie on Saturday and started playing Metal Gear Solid, which used to make me super nervous as a kid, but I‚Äôm really enjoying playing as an adult. Don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs the glow of nostalgia around the game but the story cocoons you, like watching GoldenEye.
  • I watched hours of Rick Stein on iPlayer, whom I love. He might actually be my hero. Travel, culture, and food all wrapped up. It‚Äôs the perfect escapism right now.
  • The sun came out on Sunday and looks set to be about all week, so the hammock is set-up in the garden. I got a sun burn. HELLO, SPRING.
  • Looking forward to spring vegetables making an appearance at the market. Living on carrots, parsnips, celeriac, kale, broccoli, potatoes, beetroot, jerusalem artichokes and other winter veg for the last 3‚Äì4 months has really pushed our creative talents.
  • Which reminds me, I need to finish that piece about seasonal British produce I started writing.
  • Only one more week of isolation to go.

item.title: The Isolation
item.description:
Again, these are personal weeknotes. I know most of you come here for the work tidbits, so sorry about that.

  • Being locked up for 3 days was quite hard, so by Saturday (7th) I really wanted to get out of the house. The problem was that coincided with my body‚Äôs excessive mucus production, making it hard to hide the fact I was ill in public. By chance, I happened to find the perfect cover: spicy ph·ªü. Everyone sniffs and coughs when eating hot, spicy soup. (Does you good too.)
  • Wandered down alongside the Thames. I love it there and used to walk it a lot when I lived close to St Nicholas church in Deptford. Never often made it past the Cutty Sark pub, though, and I‚Äôve been missing out.

It mentioned Samuel Pepys though, and I remembered I hadn‚Äôt read his diary yet.
  • Anyway, I‚Äôm now 330-odd chapters through the audiobook. I‚Äôm still quite surprised that his diary is where I ended up after seeking out a podcast about Britain‚Äôs adventures on the sea, but low and behold he‚Äôs actually on a ship now. So maybe it was the right thing.

  • My new speakers arrived on Friday (6th) and I‚Äôve been enjoying them an awful lot. Much more fidelty, the frequencies are treated properly, and there‚Äôs elements to songs I hadn‚Äôt picked up on before.
  • Monday evening (9th) served up a treat: Ashley Henry live-scored scenes from space at the Royal Observatory. They called it ‚Äòspace jams‚Äô. Maybe it‚Äôd work better if the music were properly arranged rather than improvised.
  • I booked tickets for Livity Sound at Mick‚Äôs Garage but it‚Äôll probably get cancelled‚Ä¶which is a shame as Peverelist B2B Pinch is just üòôüëå
  • Went to see Moses Boyd at Electric Brixton on Thursday (12th), and I dunno if I‚Äôve ever seen a drummer lead a band like that. Also, I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs fair to call him a jazz musician, feels like it boxes him in too much. Yes, it‚Äôs inspired by jazz but he plays with influences from electronic music so much. item.title: The Renovation
item.description:
Reducing the amount of time I spend thinking about work outside of work is having its benefits, so I‚Äôm only gonna chat about ‚Äòpersonal things‚Äô. My mental health is improving by working on it.

  • Parasite is a bit good, eh? The way Bong Joon Ho seamlessly stitched together different genres and moods throughout the story was masterful. After chatting to a friend who lived in South Korea for a while, I learned that it‚Äôs a fairly common storytelling technique in their culture: extraordinary stories in common settings. I think that‚Äôs why it worked so well. (I preferred the NY Times review to the Guardian‚Äôs.)
  • Went to see 1917 the following week too, which is emotive and gut-wrenching and shocking all in one. People who‚Äôve played Call of Duty will get it immediately. Maybe avoid it if you‚Äôre stressed out though, it‚Äôll have your veins pumped full of cortisol in no time.
  • The only other single-track film I‚Äôve seen is Victoria, which I caught a trailer for a few years ago and saw on a whim. It turned out to be one of the best films I‚Äôve ever seen, possibly knocking Pusher off the top spot.
  • If you‚Äôre a GDS person, watch this documentary about Spitalfields‚Äô decaying Georgian houses and the 1980s effort to restore them.
  • Bass, Mids, Tops continues to deliver on providing me with new sounds to listen to. I‚Äôve been enjoying Adrian Sherwood‚Äôs repertoire and his On-U Sound label. Dubby, playful with music tech, celebratory of soundsystem culture. The Doctor Pablo stuff is cracking.
  • As a result, there‚Äôs a few dub tracks in my February playlist, alongside new British jazz supremo Moses Boyd, a new Legowelt, Ashley Henry and a fuzzy, blues number.
  • I‚Äôve been re-reading Lean UX to give me a boost at work, and that‚Äôs been really helpful.
  • Started the designing strategy course from IDEO last week, it‚Äôs so good. Not too dissimilar to Lean methods, to be honest, but I slightly different framework to suit any business context, not just digital products. Loving it so far.
  • Ordered KRKs, which I‚Äôve been meaning to do for like 12 years. Can‚Äôt wait to hear tunes through those speakers!
  • Thinking about the below quote from Andrew Weatherall, maybe weeknotes are good for sharing but not for active thinking.

We live in a world where every minute is documented, so there‚Äôs not so much room to mythologise anything.1

  • Despite that, and in response to the quote below, I am going to say that the resurgence of rave culture is more about fashion than an actual backlash against the times we live in.

After years of fragmentation and polarisation, the joyful militancy of early rave feels poignant; the kind of unified response to political strife that this era is yet to produce.2

  • I‚Äôm going to redesign this website soon: get rid of the Javascript, make it accessible, learn Sass so that I can actually tweak the frontend. I‚Äôm using Barber as the theme currently but feel like making my own.
  • Since we‚Äôre on the cusp of an epidemic and I‚Äôve got a bad cold, I‚Äôm isolating myself at home. Prevents other people catching it, but also tension and paranoia abounds on public transport. The slightest sniffle and people are alarmed.

item.title: How we use clinics for product problems at GOV.UK
item.description:
Being a product manager can often feel like being a lone wolf. Despite working closely with a team of designers, developers and other digital specialists, you‚Äôre usually the only member of the group representing the product discipline. So who can you turn to for advice or help solving a product problem?

Communities of practice are a good remedy, loose structures that support people doing the same job to come together and help each other. The product community at GOV.UK, where I work, meet every Tuesday to talk about our practice, and a little while ago we ran a workshop to look at better ways to support our fellow product managers.1

One idea that came out was the product clinic: a safe place to bring forward your product problems and receive knowledge, experience, emotional, social or practical help from your peers.

It works like this.

  • A product manager has a problem (or a few)
  • They raise it with a panel of 2‚Äì4 product managers they work with
  • The panel steps into the PM‚Äôs shoes, responding on how they‚Äôd approach the situation

It‚Äôs pretty simple, there‚Äôs not that much structure. Topics can range from soft skills to strategy to tools, anything related to a product manager‚Äôs role. All you need is a time and place to meet, some problems to solve, and a group of empathetic peers.

The only caveat: you need a culture of openness and vulnerability in which people are comfortable opening up. (But if your community are willing to support each other, it likely already exists.)

I take notes during my clinic sessions, so that I can refer back to them later. I‚Äôll keep a list of those here because other people might find my colleagues‚Äô suggestions helpful too.

It‚Äôs better to get things out of your head rather than suffer in silence. If you‚Äôre struggling with a product problem at work, why not consider starting a clinic with your fellow product managers?2

Notes from clinic sessions

I‚Äôm in the process of writing these up, check back later or subscribe to my RSS!

  1. How do you deal with disputes with your boss? (Soft skills)
  2. What if the strategy seems confused and unclear? (Product strategy)
  3. How do you frame assumptions to be validated or invalidated? (Teams)

  1. Blog post coming soon on Inside GOV.UK, thanks to Laura ran the workshop. Here‚Äôs the output of the workshop.¬†↩

  2. I reckon all digital practitioners could benefit from clinics, not only product managers.¬†↩

item.title: The Black Dog and the Storm
item.description:
Having a bad time with the old mental health, at the moment, so I‚Äôm going to stop reflecting on work for a bit. A better divide between work and me-as-a-person will hopefully give my mood more buoyancy.

  • Had fun with Data Club last Tuesday, and I really liked that Simon came along. The pub was rather loud but we were still able to have good conversations.
  • I finished reading Doggerland. A decent book. It‚Äôs about two men ‚Äì referred to as ‚Äòthe Old Man‚Äô and ‚Äòthe Boy‚Äô throughout, except for two moments their names are mentioned ‚Äì who live on a windfarm in the southern North Sea, in a sombre dystopia. They live off canned protein and fruit, fix wind turbines, and generally don‚Äôt like each other. The Old Man dredges up artefacts from Doggerland; the Boy obsesses over fixing things. It paints their aching boredom quite vividly.

item.title: The Innovation Dogtrack
item.description:
A decent week! I feel like I‚Äôm crawling out of the mire of the past few months which, though it had both ups and downs, has been really bloody tough. It was also comforting to hear from a colleague that product managers more experienced than myself would have struggled with what we were asked to do. So that‚Äôs given me a renewed optimism.

Good things

Dan and I had a long overdue coffee at the Barbican, which was a nice spot for a rainy Monday. Kudos to Dan for picking there. We chatted about food, music, digital public services, data, data standards, machine learning, and other assorted good things.

We presented at the GOV.UK Show & Tell, the first of the year, about what we‚Äôre up to currently. It felt like this was the first time we‚Äôve had anything comprehensive to put forward, as so much of our work over the past few months has been thinking rather than doing. But people seemed interested in the work and it came as a comfort to put it out in the open. (I‚Äôd love to do the same on here but I am held back somewhat by the comms grid and controlling of narrative.)

Leanne, Head of Product, also presented GOV.UK‚Äôs future strategy to the other product managers and designers on the programme. This is not just good but great because my team (and the programme team) have been working on it for a while, but no one else had yet seen the detail. And you know what? It landed well, I think. There were plenty of useful, insightful comments but that‚Äôs the beauty of sharing it. It‚Äôs also nice to know that things we‚Äôve imagineered or repackaged make sense to our peers. So now we can get on with doing it.

The first check-in of the year with the programme team went really well, they‚Äôre bought into our mission‚Äôs goals.

Learned things

Talking about our work with the rest of the GOV.UK-as-a-service team (mapping out what we do now, so we can decide how to support things in future) was hugely cathartic. We realised we‚Äôve been acting as a mini agency team, adding flesh to Jen‚Äôs vision, which has been an honour but has also been hard. Really hard. So hooray for catharsis.

Not-work things

  • Barker‚Äôs Utility is ‚Äòa musical approach to a whole spectrum of utilitarian and transhumanist ideas‚Äô or, as we normals might say, a good album.
  • Purple sprouting broccoli is back at the food market, and it‚Äôs delicious steamed and coated in anchovy & yoghurt dressing, flaked almonds and Parmesan, FYI.
  • Fennel, celeriac and orange zest soup is velvety and perfect for Monday evenings.

Difficulties

There‚Äôs a new Chief Digital Information Officer in town who assembled many people to comment on and iterate their vision. Though it‚Äôs good to be open and collaborative, a lot of people are worried about how this new function will affect their jobs. Some brave colleagues questioned why there‚Äôs no one representing user-centred design on the senior leadership team, and that‚Äôs important. Really important.

I felt really low on Wednesday. But I sorted it out by confiding in a colleague, who was very helpful. Thank you!

Achievements

Rob, who‚Äôs come back to GOV.UK as a lead product manager, assembled a few product managers with overlapping missions and went through the future strategy to pull out the riskiest assumptions. Not only a good idea, it also encouraged the other PMs to align all of our missions on testing those assumptions. Which means there‚Äôs less weight resting on our team‚Äôs shoulders now. Thank you, Rob!

I applied to use some of my learning & development budget on a course about human-centered and business-focused strategy, which was approved, and I‚Äôm very excited about it! Expecting to learn lots of techniques that would have been useful over the past couple of months.

My post about blogging and working in the open got some traction, so thank you, people! And I was honoured that Matt Edgar mentioned it in his post about delivering digital services. His phrase of looking after the water and creating the culture for a ‚Äòvirtuous circle of productivity‚Äô prompted me to start writing another post, which I‚Äôll hopefully get out next week.

Michael‚Äôs RFC for adding metadata about attachments to content items was approved! This makes things better for the National Archives, as covered in the RFC‚Äôs comments. Never forget: the Web is beautiful, use its power for good.

item.title: Blogging and working in the open
item.description:
This is a talk I gave to the GDS product management community a year ago. It‚Äôs mostly aimed at other people working in digital transformation of government, but actually I think everyone should blog a bit.

There‚Äôs lots of ways of working in the open, blogging is just one of them.

So what is the point of blogging?

First we should define what a blog is. The noun ‚Äòblog‚Äô means a regularly updated website or web page, typically one run by an individual or small group, that is written in an informal or conversational style.

Blogs have been a part of the Web since the 1990s when web publishing tools were made easier-to-use for non-technical folk. They‚Äôve always tended to be in a diary style, allowing people to talk about what they do, their interests and anything they please.

But what‚Äôs the point of blogging in government?

Blogging helps to

  • open up government
  • form a dialogue with our audience
  • share what we‚Äôve learnt

It‚Äôs really all about starting conversations and sharing knowledge. The audience might be fellow service creators or it might be end users.

But it‚Äôs worthwhile taking this a step further. Blogging is all about working in the open. Working in the open causes you to be honest about your work and makes it easier to collaborate with smart communities of peers.

I‚Äôll expand on that‚Ä¶

What‚Äôs the point of being open?

The Government Transformation Strategy says that ‚Äòa culture of open, digitally enabled policy making and service delivery is critical to our future success.‚Äô It‚Äôs written into our values as an organisation too: ‚ÄòMake things open, it makes things better.‚Äô

Being open is about the importance of working across organisational boundaries to make things better for users.

If someone in Department A talks about a particular problem and someone in Department B says they‚Äôve encountered the same thing, they‚Äôre likely to ignore the boundaries and differences between their departments and explore the problem together.

The shared goal is making things better for users and working in the open helps facilitate that.

So, more formally, what are the goals of openness?

And these don‚Äôt just cover blogging, they can be attributed to our day-to-day practice too.

The goals of openness

These come from Open Matt.

Participation: it‚Äôs rocket-fuel for smart collaboration. Speaking outside of your organisational box can attract other people, get conversations started and accelerate collaboration. (Joined-up working, yeah?)

Agility: speed, flexibility, getting shit done. When you work in the open, you‚Äôre more likely to check what you‚Äôre saying before putting it out there. It encourages a better, more accountable working practice, as well as working out how to build the right thing.

Momentum: communities want to push boulders that are already moving. Simply put, working in the open is cheap PR. People love to get involved in exciting projects headed in the right direction. One of my favourite stories is how Neil Williams got offered a job at GDS because he blogged so enthusiastically about a single government website, and Tom Loosemore happened to spot it. But you see this with the Local Digital Coalition too. Teams in previously under-the-radar councils becoming visibly active in improving their authority‚Äôs ways of working.

Testing and rapid prototyping: refining as we go. Working in the open creates better feedback and testing loops, and the history of changes is documented. You have the opportunity to welcome a more diverse set of voices to comment on your work, which is always a good thing.

Leverage: getting greater bang from our limited resources. And again, blogging is really cheap PR. I‚Äôve personally made a ton of good connections I didn‚Äôt expect simply by talking about what I‚Äôve done. Don‚Äôt worry about making things too polished though, raw honesty (or slightly processed honesty ‚Äì runny honey) is some of the secret sauce to making it work. (That means you can talk about failure as well as success.)

So why blog about our work?

Blogging is not about thought leadership or public performance, it‚Äôs about actively feeding the conversation around agile, user-centred transformation.

By putting our experiences out there and talking about the new challenges we‚Äôre facing, people can empathise or respond, developing the transformation project we‚Äôre all a part of.

And we should be more open to talking about failure too, or announcing when things didn‚Äôt go to plan. Not to call ourselves out but help others later down the line.

This is an excellent quote from Ellie Craven who used to be the PM on GOV.UK Registers.

‚ÄòThe more we obscure how we work, and why it‚Äôs valuable, the harder we‚Äôll find it to gain broad organisational support for the next project, and the one after that.‚Äô

Talking about our work helps us better describe it and its value across government. It also gives you a chance to show your working without that person needing to attend a talk or Show & Tell.

And then she goes one better‚Ä¶

‚ÄòWe should do the hard work to make this simpler for those who come after us.‚Äô

That‚Äôs my emphasis, but talking about our work now helps people who might one day step into our shoes.

So going back to what I said before, blogging helps to

  • open up government
  • form a dialogue with our audience
  • share what we‚Äôve learnt

Some principles

Some principles (for civil servants) then.

The Civil Service Code underpins everything. Stick by that.

But the first real rule, don‚Äôt be a dick.

Try not to be the person to say the wrong thing or inadvertently give away a ministerial plan or cause offence to a team member. None of that is good, but you can mitigate it by asking a second pair of eyes to look over your work.

Ask someone before mentioning them, they might be staying away from the ‚Äòspotlight‚Äô. One of my colleagues doesn‚Äôt use social media, for example, and wants to stay away from it, so I only ever referred to them as ‚Äòour delivery manager‚Äô.

Spoilers suck, so avoid telling another team‚Äôs story. They might be doing great things but try not to build too much of a picture if you must mention it. They should have the right to cause a splash.

How can I start blogging?

Hopefully that‚Äôs done enough to convince you to get started. So here‚Äôs a few tips to get going.

Add a ‚ÄòBlog‚Äô column to your kanban board. It‚Äôll help you consider which pieces of work are worth sharing and talking about. You might even build up a few stories per sprint to talk about. Break it down into smaller chunks, it‚Äôs much easier.

If you want to start small and maybe try something more personal, weeknotes are a great way to get going. Weeknotes are personal reflections on your working week to learn from what you‚Äôve done and improve your practice from week to week. You simply write about what you‚Äôve done and how you feel about how it went.

There‚Äôs an excellent community on the #weeknotes hashtag on Twitter who can give you ideas, but you can also just ask for help. They‚Äôre super friendly.

It‚Äôs worth saying that blogging isn‚Äôt an easy thing to start, you‚Äôll probably get ‚Äòthe fear‚Äô about receiving criticism on your work or thoughts. But that‚Äôs fine, my advice is to just dive in and have a go. Usually your fears don‚Äôt match reality, and there‚Äôs an amazing community there to comment and help if you‚Äôre struggling anyway.

And if you‚Äôre worried about writing about work in the public domain, don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs OK. You have permission. People high up at director level are doing it, just take a look at what Matt Edgar, Rox Heaton and Ross Ferguson are doing.

You don‚Äôt need any money to get started, really, you can spin up a blog in minutes using platforms like Wordpress and Medium. It‚Äôs a quick way to test out the practice and see if it‚Äôs right for you.

If you‚Äôd like to create your own website, static site generators like Jekyll and Hugo are low-tech ways to get started. You might have heard of GitHub Pages which runs on Jekyll. You simply feed it some Markdown files and it builds a website for you. GitHub Pages is free too, and it‚Äôs a good way to become more familiar with Git in general.

And you needn‚Äôt worry about having to promote your blog posts either. Services like Missinglettr, Zapier and Quuu Promote will syndicate your blog posts on social media automatically, helping your posts to get a greater reach.

You may become a self-facilitating media node. That‚Äôs fine. The goal is to share knowledge and passion and get more people involved in agile, user-centred transformation.

A note on passion

At the end of the talk, I asked members of the audience to raise their hand if they wanted to work at GDS after reading one of its blog posts. 75 per cent of people put their hand up.

Thank you to Matt Jukes, Amanda Smith, Giles Turnbull, Neil Williams, Dan Barrett, Ellie Craven, Sam Villis, Jonathan Kerr and the #weeknotes folks, stalwarts of the blogging and working in the open community who inspired this.

item.title: The Edging Forward
item.description:
Writing notes on a Monday is hard. Hoping to return to writing on a Saturday soon, although maybe I should try something more lean. I‚Äôm going to add a section that‚Äôs not about work, anyway.

This week‚Äôs mantra was ‚ÄòBe stubborn on the vision but flexible on the details‚Äô.

Good things

We reviewed some more evidence, threw together some ideas, drew up a hypothesis framework, and then tried a Value‚ÄìEffort map to sort the ideas based on which might provide the highest return-on-investment in terms of learning. Conversations around the ideas taught us that we didn‚Äôt know enough about users‚Äô pain points, so we‚Äôre going to collect more evidence first.

We chatted with Data Labs to see where our teams could hook up, and there‚Äôs plenty of opportunity to learn from each other ‚Äì which is great!

We welcomed Ned to the team as our new user researcher, since Lisa is heading back to Amsterdam. Really glad to have him join!

An evening out with Adam and Trilly was great.

Matt and I suggested some improvements to Jon & Arfah‚Äôs great ‚ÄòIntroduction to Product Management‚Äô slides.

Learned things

I‚Äôve been thinking about management vs. leadership a fair bit, and there were a couple of moments in the week when that clicked.

Not-work things

  • Bass, Mids, Tops by Joe Muggs arrived.
  • Finished reading Infinite Detail and fuck me, it‚Äôs so good. Great characters and development. Incredibly visceral. Decent plot. Evocative setting. The chapter about record shops and soundsystems and dubstep made me miss my bus stop. BUY IT.
  • Roots, Reggae and Rebellion is a really good podcast if, like me, you can‚Äôt remember your lessons in Rastafarianism fron year 6. My mind drew parallels between Rasta thinking and circular systems, but I haven‚Äôt done any proper analysis on that.
  • Anyway, the show made a good point about the decriminalised cannabis markets (in the USA, Netherlands, Canada, etc.) being propped up on the Jamaican subculture and not making any contribution back.
  • Since a few friends enjoyed the annual discoveries playlist, I‚Äôve started a monthly one too.
  • Went for lunch at Terroirs on Saturday. Still banging. Winter tomatoes are decent, eh.
  • Alex said that my website doesn‚Äôt work with JavaScript turned off, which means I‚Äôm probably going to have to make my own Jekyll theme.

Difficulties

Juggling two teams while being pulled in a few directions and contributing to slide decks for government folk.

There‚Äôs still more effort needed in finding the right scope for team, the right goals to help us learn. (But if I‚Äôm honest, I do think we made progress on that this week.)

Achievements

Our learning & development budget is signed off by senior management and I‚Äôd been thinking about going on a course to learn more about strategy and leadership. Our Head of Product, Leanne, said she‚Äôd support any requests I made!

Matt agreed to meet and nerd out over product management every Friday! We‚Äôre going to do a lean coffee, choosing subjects to chat about that we might have been thinking about or dealing with recently.

Felt closer to my practice this week!

Bookmarks

item.title: The Request for Help
item.description:
Writing weeknotes help me reflect on my practice as a product manager. Right now, I‚Äôm feeling a need for mentorship. Though I know the theory well and have kept plates spinning successfully in the past, it‚Äôd be dishonest (and harmful to me and my teams, in the long-run) not to admit I need a little help. How does one find a mentor?

I‚Äôve been grateful for help from seasoned professionals before, so I‚Äôll be reaching out for their help, but if you happen to read my weeknotes and would be willing to help out, please do drop me a line. And a huge thank-you in advance!

Good things

Rob came back as lead product manager. Within 24 hours he‚Äôd already made some cracking recommendations and made good observations. I‚Äôm really pleased he‚Äôs back, his measured, well-structured approach has been missing.

The team is excited to experiment! We‚Äôre probably going to use experiments -> proofs-of-concept -> MVP as an approach to begin with, using the honesty of retrospectives as a point to pivot our practice.

The first GOV.UK product managers‚Äô weekly community get-together was very interesting, I‚Äôm glad Laura suggested and facilitated it. As a product manager is often a lone wolf, we looked at times we‚Äôve needed support and how we might better support each other. We were pleased to see a blog post on the exact same subject pop up a couple days‚Äô later from our colleagues in Department for Education!

Chatted with Ganesh about how our teams can work together this quarter. There‚Äôs lots of ways for each team to bounce off each other, learning and exploring in unison. I‚Äôve missed working alongside him, so it‚Äôll be good.

Also, Antonia came back, hooray! She kindly offered to take Licensing back from me, so we worked through some things with GOV.UK Pay‚Äôs Katie.

Learned things

Learning lots about engaging with executive teams, policy & strategy colleagues, and how we package up work for ministers and other senior government bods. I contributed to an expression of interest for a new collaborative working fund and presented to a finance committee on the vision for GOV.UK.

After asking, Jen was kind enough to provide some good feedback: I‚Äôm calm, collected and explain things well, but did lean on GDS-speak once or twice which we need to be careful about as an organisation.

Difficulties

I‚Äôve been feeling quite out-of-touch with my practice of late, perhaps based on the fact I‚Äôm working on a gnarly opportunity space with little experience in laying down and managing experimental approaches. As mentioned in the weeknotes before Christmas, I‚Äôd been using a single-product mindset which meant we fell down a little. Losing momentum can also be the downfall of a team, especially when the push and pull forces of management and leadership aren‚Äôt flowing freely.

I need to work a little more on my soft skills and I‚Äôm going to lean on mentors and coaches more.

Achievements

I think I managed to sum up some of our work into a blog post. A few more tweaks (thanks Angus) and it should be there.

Kicking off the ‚ÄòGOV.UK as a service‚Äô work ‚Äì looking at the purposes, people, processes and perceptions of our platform ‚Äì went pretty well!

Collecting and reviewing evidence for a whole problem happened.

People have been kind about the Boring Magic post. Thank you. Stickers coming soon. (It‚Äôs also syndicated on Medium.)

item.title: Boring magic
item.description:
Recently I‚Äôve been working on a team thinking about what digital government services might be like in the near future. Conor, our interaction designer, summed up the last 9 years rather well.

‚ÄòWe essentially create boring magic.‚Äô

It just rolls off the tongue.

There are things that people have to do ‚Äì like pay tax, register a vehicle, work out what to do with dead farm animals, etc. ‚Äì which are boring. These things only exist because of government. Our job is to make those tedious experiences a bit magical: simple, clear and fast. All the hallmarks of convenience, that works the first time.

Other (more clever) people have written about using the word ‚Äòmagical‚Äô in association with digital public services. That, in the early days, making ‚Äònew kinds of irresistible content felt magical‚Äô. But that because some digital public services are actually really important parts of people‚Äôs lives, particularly in government, things are much more serious ‚Äì because what we design is inherently political.

I agree with those people completely. But with this term ‚Äì boring magic ‚Äì we stumbled upon a way of describing the experience we should provide, in a humble way.

There‚Äôs a barber I occasionally visit in Deptford. He often forgets that I‚Äôve been in before and will usually ask me what I do for a living. ‚ÄòI work on GOV.UK, you know, the government website?‚Äô

‚ÄòAh yes! Do you know, we had to apply for our daughter‚Äôs passport recently and it was good. All done within 10 minutes. Took the picture on her phone. Got straight back to watching telly, there was none of that faff in going to the Post Office, a photographer, all of that.‚Äô

He has no idea of the relative complexity of what he‚Äôs done. All the gubbins happening behind the curtain. He‚Äôs just done what he needs to do, and moved on with his life.

That‚Äôs magic. It‚Äôs pleasing, but boring enough to move on from. Completely pedestrian, no exaltations; he was just pleased it did what he needed it to do.

We make these boring things as magical as possible, within the limits of how magical tedium should be. Things don‚Äôt have to be whizzy, they just have to work well enough. Because magic isn‚Äôt the end goal.

When we‚Äôre thinking about digital public services of the future, we can temper our ambitions and look to the past for lessons. ‚ÄòTechnology alone will not create a better world.‚Äô

Thanks to Jonathan for his help in editing this, and thanks to Conor for the sticker and this wonderful phrase.

item.title: The Festive Break
item.description:
It‚Äôs been enjoyable seeing people‚Äôs personal weeknotes springing up, writing about what they got up to and thought about as a person rather than a work-machine cog. Mark does good ones, Anna too, and my RSS-to-Pocket Zapier feed is growing nicely. Feels like more people are trying to make the web personal again.

So here‚Äôs what I did or thought about during the festive break.

Books were read

I finished reading Eden Medina‚Äôs Cybernetic Revolutionaries, which tells the story of Project Cybersyn, an endeavour by the Chilean government to create a distributed decision support system using computers and feedback loops to help measure and manage the economy. In layman‚Äôs terms, it‚Äôs Estonia‚Äôs e-government but done in the early 1970s. It‚Äôs really worth a read, lots of food-for-thought on the boundary between technology and politics, worker/citizen participation, etc.

I started and finished Erebus: the story of a ship by Michael Palin, which is all about the Arctic and Antarctic exploratory missions of the 1840s, on HMSs Erebus and Terror. I first came across the story after watching AMC‚Äôs The Terror on a flight back from Thailand in 2018, a really neatly done little series based on a book written by Dan Simmons. Having only read material from the National Maritime Museum beforehand, Palin‚Äôs book does well to frame the ambition of the missions, their respective successes and failures and ‚Äì in the extreme ‚Äì tries to paint a picture of what it‚Äôd be like living stranded on a ship in the Arctic ice for five years. Spoiler: it‚Äôd be awful.

After that, I picked up Tim Maugham‚Äôs Infinite Detail, a cautionary tale about the technology-augmented anthropecene, the Internet-of-Everything and basic human values. It‚Äôs set in Bristol too, making wry and humorous takes on the city, but also becoming something of a love letter to Brizzle. Makes me miss being in the city. I‚Äôm recommending it to everyone, and it‚Äôs only ¬£2 on Kindle.

Hills were walked

Ventured up Carn Fadryn, a five-hectare Iron Age hillfort in North Wales, and shared the walk on Go Jauntly. I‚Äôm a real nerd for trying to get into the mindset of ancient Britons and Carn Fadryn is as evocative as Caer Caradoc. The roundhouses have stone bases, hidden in a nook on the northwestern side of the hill, to shelter from the gales blowing off Porth Neigwl. We were nearly blown off the top actually, so you can imagine how harsh a landscape it would have been to live in with wool clothes and woad walls.

Spied a petrified forest down on the beach at Porth Neigwl too, that was cool.

Food was eaten (and thought about)

Ate too much, naturally.

But also we had a think about our food shopping and cooking. I want to write separately about trying to stick to a mostly vegetarian diet based on seasonal British product, but we got a few veg cooking books for Christmas to help with that. Nigel Slater‚Äôs Greenfeast: autumn/winter, Anna Jones‚Äôs The Modern Cook‚Äôs Year and old-favourite Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall‚Äôs River Cottage Veg Every Day.

Other bits

  • A subscription to the New York Times is worth it for the mini crossword alone.
  • Setting a more strict Screen Time and Downtime regimen has helped me be a bit more mindful about how I‚Äôm using my waking hours.
  • I bought tickets to see Joe Armon-Jones, Moses Boyd and the Swamp 81 crew.
  • Tempted by South Circular too.
  • I‚Äôm really enjoying cigars.

item.title: The Helping Hand
item.description:
We‚Äôre out of the pre-election period which means I can probably get back to talking about work now, although I preferred the style of the last few weeks. Talking about topics I‚Äôd been thinking about in the week was good for me; not sure whether my usual readers found it useful though. It‚Äôs still useful to reflect on my working week but I‚Äôd like to be more open about it.

Good things

After spending an hour with our new Head of Policy & Strategy, Rachel, she‚Äôd managed to pull together our work and make sense of it. She really helped with the sense-making, actually, asking probing questions that caused us to explain something or develop our thinking a little more.

The next day we had a session on how product managers and policy & strategy folk can work better together. There‚Äôs a lot of overlap in the roles, which could cause problems depending on who is presenting work or constraints to Cabinet Office. But having the conversation and realising that was the value of the meeting, otherwise we may not have realised.

I went to a workshop about managing stress, put on by the programme team. It was decent and I got to learn some techniques for improving my mood. They suggest making incremental improvements, 1 per cent per day, which is quite agile.

The Christmas Show & Tell was great! I‚Äôm so proud of the Search team, who‚Äôve been continuing work on improving search results as well as making design changes. They showed off a new tool which allows them to collect qualitative data on the relevance of search results, and those readings can be fed into the Learn to Rank algorithm. To be honest, I was jealous not to have been on that ride with them! Top crew. I miss them.

Federico explained the identity market to me. It was both fascinating and enlightening. Government could play a big part in making life online better, I reckon.

Learned things

We gave the Theory of Change workshop another try, instead focusing on a particular problem space rather than the high levels of a system. It went pretty well, but it would be good to nail it. Having clear boundaries on the scope of the problem space is possibly the winner. Also, the suggested running order on Nesta‚Äôs DIY Toolkit doesn‚Äôt match up to the method elsewhere, and I think we could revisit that. It helped us see the link between problems, solutions and outcomes in a massive system though.

On Friday I realised that I‚Äôve approached the last couple months‚Äô work from the wrong perspective. I‚Äôd been applying single-product processes to a wider, more complicated, systems-level problem. Some things have gone well, others haven‚Äôt. As soon as I realised this, I started crystallising some discoveries and alphas that need to happen, in sequence, to validate the ideas we‚Äôve had. This sort of roadmapping is senior product stuff, taking a step back from team-level tasks to programme-wide projects.

On realising it, I instantly felt bad at having not been a good leader for the team. Though I know I‚Äôm not entirely to blame (circumstances are circumstances), I still don‚Äôt want that to happen again. I‚Äôve learned things but the hard way.

Difficulties

A team planning session was painful, but I‚Äôm grateful to those who put the effort in.

The stress workshop came with a trigger warning but we ended up being triggered anyway.

Achievements

Picking which battles to fight.

item.title: Reading List Picks of 2019
item.description:
Here‚Äôs a bunch of articles and blog posts that got me thinking about digital government, product management, design thinking, the World Wide Web and data this year. There‚Äôs also a couple of nice stories I enjoyed thrown in. Oh, and some stuff about attention too, because this list is full of useful distractions.

I‚Äôve not included anything about privacy, which I should have, but I think that probably deserves its own post.

Digital government

Just enough Internet: Why public service Internet should be a model of restraint

Heavyweight thinking on good, responsible technology in public service from Rachel Coldicutt, which has been this year‚Äôs hot topic alongside privacy. Rachel‚Äôs piece does well to bring together thinking from across the public service space, including sessions from MozFest 2018, viewing it through a lens of sustainability.

Read Just enough Internet: Why public service Internet should be a model of restraint.

There is no such thing as the government

This was posted in 2010, around the time Martha Lane Fox‚Äôs report on Directgov was published, leading to the creation of Government Digital Service and GOV.UK. In it Stefan Czerniawski talks about how the dream for joined-up government services has been around for years, and it‚Äôs a key historical text for anyone working in the current era of transformation1. (There‚Äôs bonus archived blog posts from Tom, Neil, and Jukesie.)

Read There is no such thing as the government.

The problem with the service lifecycle

The service design lifecycle in government has four stages: discovery, alpha, beta, live. It‚Äôs an agile technique from the world of software development, and its aim is to help teams and organisations create new things while reducing waste. But it‚Äôs a linear strategy with a resolute end, it doesn‚Äôt set you up for what‚Äôs next. Sanjay put forward the idea of the lifecycle as a spiral, which I really like as it helps you think about step-changes. You might have digitised a bunch of paper forms, but how might you discover the bigger problem to solve?

Read The problem with the service lifecycle.

Data-sharing in government: why it‚Äôs time for a new approach

If bits of government start using more data to design and deliver things, what will people think about government and will they trust it? This is one of many pieces Richard has written in his software is politics genre, but it‚Äôs a good one for considering how the social contract plays into trust models and data re-use. Essentially: there should be clear lines of accountability and responsibility for citizens to have recourse.

Read Data-sharing in government: why it‚Äôs time for a new approach.

Product management & design thinking

Right question, wrong answer: agile stakeholder management

Most product teams will know about HiPPOs ‚Äì the highest paid person in the organisation ‚Äì and their opinions. Sometimes senior people will ask why a team hasn‚Äôt produced a particular output, and Matt puts forward a helpful mindset for breaking that down. It‚Äôs easy to get dismayed or irked in those situations but this piece sets a principled approach.

Read Right question, wrong answer: agile stakeholder management.

Resources for applying a systems lens to your work

I spent a lot of time looking at the bigger picture in work this year and came across this post in the summer. It has a a bunch of great resources for how to address root causes, not symptoms of problems ‚Äì systems-thinking. Even reading the first book on the list, Dan Hill‚Äôs Dark Matter and Trojan Horses, changed the way I work. Make your way through the list, it‚Äôs great. Shout-out to Aly (and Will, of course).

Read Resources for applying a systems lens to your work.

A New Social Contract

The first post in a four-part series on redesigning democracy from Alastair Parvin. He‚Äôs done incredibly well to set the problems and proposed solutions within their context, making it all relatable. An expert use of storytelling and systems-thinking to propose new futures, with a nod to government as a platform.

Read A New Social Contract.

Why you should stop using product roadmaps and try GIST planning

A decent framework from Itamar Gilad that wraps in Lean Startup methods, OKRs, and a pipeline for testing ideas, all sat beneath the organisation‚Äôs shared goals and strategy. I tried it out on the Search team and we made some good progress. A good way to avoid the agile build trap, do more prototyping, and empower product teams to deliver outcomes.

Read Why you should stop using product roadmaps and try GIST planning.

I Read About ‚ÄúDesign For Trust‚Äù So You Don‚Äôt Have To

Does what it says on the tin. A compendium of links to and a summary of many ‚Äòdesign for trust‚Äô posts from across the Web. (It‚Äôs worth reading all the content the author draws on though!)

Read I Read About ‚ÄúDesign For Trust‚Äù So You Don‚Äôt Have To.

The world is distracted

The Machine Stops

Either peak smartphone isn‚Äôt far off or we‚Äôve reached it already. The late neurologist Oliver Sacks writes about the disappearence of old civilities, where people have replaced talking to their neighbours with talking to their phones. But there‚Äôs hope in this piece too, that people will realise the need to sustain the richness of human cultures. And since more of us are putting our phones down, I‚Äôm hopeful too.

Read The Machine Stops.

The attention economy

Owen Williams puts forward the idea that most products are competing for the space in front of your eyeballs. Attention is now a commodity as much as technology, and the only limit is the population and the number of waking hours.

Read The attention economy.

The Case for Doing Nothing

Niksen is the Dutch concept of embracing boredom to stop ourselves being so busy. It‚Äôs a bit like mindfulness, only you don‚Äôt need to pay Headspace a subscription fee to learn how to do it. This piece makes the case for doing nothing with purpose.

Read The Case for Doing Nothing.

The Web and data

30 years on, what‚Äôs next #ForTheWeb?

The World Wide Web is 30 years old, so I couldn‚Äôt not include this. Since you‚Äôre using the Web, please read it!

Read 30 years on, what‚Äôs next #ForTheWeb?.

The Internet‚Äôs Back-to-the-Land Movement

Following on from the piece by Lowtech magazine in last year‚Äôs picks, this piece by Becca Abbe talks about moving off-grid in a digital sense: opting out of mainstream internet providers and building independent mesh networks or a peer-to-peer Web. Whatever the solution, making things more sustainable is a critical consideration for the next few decades.

Read The Internet‚Äôs Back-to-the-Land Movement.

The Rise and Demise of RSS

RSS is one of those wonderful Web technologies, meaning you can follow updates from anyone across the world. In simple terms, it‚Äôs a bit like tweets without Twitter. But depsite getting off to a good start, RSS has all but disappeared as people have moved to centralised silos like Twitter. The reason? Too many competing standards. The story of RSS teaches us that a better, more open Web will come from getting better at working together.

Read The Rise and Demise of RSS.

The Semantic Web identity crisis: in search of the trivialities that never were

In a similar vein to the story of RSS, Ruben Verborgh talks about the last two decades of research into the Semantic Web ‚Äì and how it hasn‚Äôt really changed the world much. The dream was big, the vision was crystal clear, but through lack of dogfooding the dream hasn‚Äôt been delivered. But if semantic technologies can be brough out of the research space and into the world of product development‚Ä¶who knows?

Read The Semantic Web identity crisis: in search of the trivialities that never were.

Data as institutional memory

Another excellent post about standards, from Adam, plumping for collaboratively developed standards as part of a system, not just a by-product of policy and legislation. ‚ÄòFix the plumbing by identifying the leaks‚Äô rang in my head for a couple of days after reading this, it‚Äôs a great analogy. Great stuff on designing data as infrastructure in the 21st century. (Adam running his mouth in the pub is something I enjoy being around, it produces gems like this.)

Read Data as institutional memory.

Why Data Is Never Raw

I don‚Äôt believe we should aim for data-driven futures because it renders human decisions as useless. Instead we should be data-informed, reading metrics and measures to inform our decisions. But it‚Äôs worth remembering that data is never raw: the schema by which you collect and read data goes some way to defining how you‚Äôll interpret it. In The New Atlantis, Nick Barrowman talks about the seductive myth of information free of human judgment.

Read Why Data Is Never Raw.

Unicorns, Ontologies and How the Mind Organizes the World

The world of structured data was a right headf**k when I first joined Porism. Since there‚Äôs much chatter about ontologies, taxonomies, registers and other aspects of semantic technologies at work now, I always send this article to anyone starting out. Who knew a story about Marco Polo would help frame it so well?!

Read Unicorns, Ontologies and How the Mind Organizes the World.

Just good stories

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not leaving this bar until we‚Äôve come up with such a great idea that I can‚Äôt sack you‚Äù

The story of how BBC iPlayer came about because of a drunken brainstorm as told by Tony Ageh, who was the project director for the thing. It‚Äôs funny and uplifting and wonderfully down-to-earth.

Read ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not leaving this bar until we‚Äôve come up with such a great idea that I can‚Äôt sack you‚Äù.

How William Gibson Keeps His Science Fiction Real

William Gibson invented the word ‚Äòcyberspace‚Äô and, along with it, the cyberpunk movement and everything that inspired. I grew up on The Matrix, Blade Runner, Johnny Mnemonic and the video game Deus Ex, so it‚Äôs pleasing to hear how the books that inspired those worlds ‚Äì beginning with Gibson‚Äôs debut Neuromancer ‚Äì came together.

Read How William Gibson Keeps His Science Fiction Real.

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt all about drugs‚Äù

By talking to teenagers about the acid house movement of the 1980s, Jeremy Deller managed to explore the period and what it was really all about, without falling on the obvious answer of drugs. This is a good interview about his documentary, Everybody in the Place: an Incomplete History of Britain 1984‚Äì92, but you should definitely also watch the doc.

Read ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt all about drugs‚Äù.

The Brexit Warnings to Be Found in Sheep Grazing in a London Park

An overlapping of stories about the commons, Boudica, Hampstead Heath, and thoughts on Brexit back in September. (I mostly like it for the agricultural experiment and the archeology, but there‚Äôs something in there for politicos too.)

Read The Brexit Warnings to Be Found in Sheep Grazing in a London Park.

The real-life Ali G

Can‚Äôt remember why I came across this story about Tim Westwood but it‚Äôs absolutely cracking.

Read The real-life Ali G.

In 1968, computers got personal

The story of how ‚Äòthe mother of all demos‚Äô changed the world, moving computing from the research space to the commercial space. By helping people imagine a future in which everyone had a computer, we now do.

Read In 1968, computers got personal.

  1. If anyone has stratified the eras of government transformation, digital and beyond, please do let me know!¬†↩

item.title: The Niksen
item.description:
As mentioned in my previous weeknotes, we‚Äôre still in the pre-election period which means I can‚Äôt talk about work we‚Äôve been doing. These are meditations on user-centred design practice and other fluff, not my usual weeknotes.

Is there anything better than a perfectly timed holiday? Two weeks away in Cuba really sorted me out, giving me time and space to switch off fully. I‚Äôve come back to work feeling energised and with renewed perspective, enthused to tackle the challenges we‚Äôre taking on. Which is a marked difference to how depleted I felt in November.

Since I was in Cuba, I read Hemingway‚Äôs The Old Man and the Sea, which he wrote there, and one line resounded with that feeling of depletion: ‚ÄúNow is no time to think of what you do not have. Think of what you can do with what there is.‚Äù

Switching off

Cuba is a simple country. You take more pleasure in the availability of things rather than their variety. There‚Äôs plenty of food, for example, but the menu is always the same. Better to have food than not, for sure. There‚Äôs limited access to the Internet too. To get online we had to buy cards with codes on, which gave us access for an hour at a time. It meant there was plenty of incentive to switch off.

That‚Äôs quite different from our always-connected nature in the UK. Having little to do meant a better appreciation for each waking moment, and I realised how many of those we fill with crap.

It‚Äôs weird. It‚Äôs weird that we spend so much time distracting ourselves, mostly with our phones. Oliver Sacks touched on it in a piece for the New Yorker:

These gadgets, already ominous in 2007, have now immersed us in a virtual reality far denser, more absorbing, and even more dehumanizing. I am confronted every day with the complete disappearance of the old civilities. Social life, street life, and attention to people and things around one have largely disappeared, at least in big cities, where a majority of the population is now glued almost without pause to phones or other devices‚Äîjabbering, texting, playing games, turning more and more to virtual reality of every sort.

So I didn‚Äôt do that. When I wasn‚Äôt chatting to my partner or playing cards or drinking rum or reading, I was just sitting there, doing nothing. It was nice. I just unplugged. And it turns out that being completely idle is good for you, good for your creativity.

Ms. Mann‚Äôs research has found that daydreaming ‚Äî an inevitable effect of idleness ‚Äî ‚Äúliterally makes us more creative, better at problem-solving, better at coming up with creative ideas.‚Äù For that to happen, though, total idleness is required.

That‚Äôs from a New York Times article about doing nothing. The Dutch call it niksen and it‚Äôs all about purposefully becoming bored. Forcing yourself to do nothing. I suppose niksen is a bit like mindfulness, only it‚Äôs harder to make a subscription-based product for boredom.

So with the festive break coming up, I‚Äôm looking forward to spending time doing fuck all again.

There‚Äôs a great podcast on Cuba‚Äôs digital revolution from the BBC, worth checking out.

Theory of Change

In attempting to frame a vision for change within a system, Leighton suggested to Will that we might try the Theory of Change. It looks a bit like a Lean canvas but for social impact, which I think is applicable to some civic technology projects.

It spurs you to think about measurable outcomes against your intended impact too ‚Äì which is fab. So I described it as a cross between a Lean canvas and OKRs, although it won‚Äôt help you think about cost or revenue like product frameworks might.

Like a Lean Canvas and OKRs, it doesn‚Äôt take well to high-level, generalised systems. It really needs some specificity and to focus on a domain. Writing ‚ÄòThis is for everyone‚Äô in the target audience column is a bad idea; better to have several theories of change for different problem spaces to highlight the shared problems. That means your measurable outcomes will be specific, measurable, achievable, realistic and timely too.

Bookmarks

Some bits and pieces I read over the past few weeks.

  • The New Vocabulary: how we‚Äôre wrong about ‚Äòconsent‚Äô, 7 mins
  • Using speculative design to explore the future of Open Justice, 4 mins
  • Governance or trust?, 3 mins
  • Introduction to Speculative Design Practice ‚Äì Speculative, 14 mins

  • Britain‚Äôs Dirty Election, 5 mins

item.title: Revivalist aesthetic: musical discoveries from 2019
item.description:
Last year I put together a playlist of music I‚Äôd loved or first listened to in 2018 and, genre-wise, it was relatively varied. Beats, jazz-funk, rock, club heaters, hip-hop and some essential bass music. This year‚Äôs list, however, is quite different to that. It‚Äôs a playlist of songs that are mostly all the same, to be honest.

2019 has been the year of the revivalist sound, with young producers harkening back to the days of 1990s rave with pumping modern tributes. The stand-out release for me has been Soundbwoy Killah‚Äôs Halcyon Daze, an LP ‚Äòsuffused‚Ä¶with the heady fug of rave memories and long nights in the dance‚Äô (as told by Bleep). They‚Äôre tunes that make you want to go raving again, even if your own halcyon days were 2006‚Äì2013, not the decade previous.

This playlist is packed with those kinds of tunes, it reeks of nostalgia.

In a way, it‚Äôs a mournful playlist. Going out these days isn‚Äôt like what it used to be (*cough* old man *cough*). In reviving the warehouse rave, clubs like Printworks have mass-marketed and stripped away the original appeal: underground folklore. It‚Äôs something Burial touches on in this interview with Wire magazine.

The UK was changing in a different direction, away from us. Maybe the feeling of the UK in clubs and stuff back then, it wasn‚Äôt as artificial, self-aware or created by the internet. It was more rumour, underground folklore. No mobile phones back then. Anyone could go into the night and they had to seek it out. Because you could see it in people, you could see it in their eyes. Those ravers were at the edge at their lives, they weren‚Äôt running ahead or falling behind, they were just right there and the tunes meant everything.

There was a time when I respected music in that way. These days I don‚Äôt give it enough dedication.

But then again, maybe it‚Äôs an optimistic playlist. The music I‚Äôve listened to and loved in 2019 seems to be sounds of a remembered era, and I‚Äôm really keen to go out and hear music again. I miss it: the swaying, the lights, the sweat, the laughs. So 41 tracks remembering all that has sparked my keenness to get dancing again.

Anyway, that‚Äôs enough blabbering. Here‚Äôs the playlist of tracks I discovered or loved in 2019. Listen on Spotify or Bandcamp through Buy Music Club.

And here‚Äôs to getting back out there. See you in the dance, front-left.
