item.title: The Road Ahead
item.description:
It‚Äôs the end of quarter 4, 2018/19. We‚Äôve done a heck of a lot and there‚Äôs palpable excitement at what‚Äôs to come next quarter. Keep an eye out for the GOV.UK Roadmap 2019/20, which we‚Äôre hoping to launch very, very soon.

Five Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

The end-of-quarter Show & Tell was really top notch and it was impressive to see how much teams had achieved during an intense political period. The EU Exit Voltron mega-team have managed to churn out heaps of goodness for people, and it‚Äôs seriously impressive that Sam managed to turn the ‚Äòdynamic FAQs‚Äô request into ‚ÄòNo, but here‚Äôs some improvements to Search‚Äô.

Platform Health have managed to get concrete numbers on how much load the platform can put up with too, which means they can look at the architecture strategy going forward. Content Data have added reading time to their metrics, meaning you can find out how long it takes to read things like the Budget 2018 (answer: 3h 26m). Filtered lists (we call those Finders) are more consistent, and a machine-learning algorithm has helped humans curate related links on pages, which other humans find useful.

I got to announce that we‚Äôre saving taxpayers ¬£35,000 a year off the back of our Search Resilience & Performance mission, and I wrote it on the side of a bus. Then I showed how we might (I must stress, might) personalise the experience of interacting with government, based on what we‚Äôd found from speaking to international governments and senior stakeholders. Next we need to find a politician willing to spend the political capital required to make a natively digital nation a reality in the UK. 1

And it was a boon to wrap up the quarter knowing that Government Communication Service and the Chief Executive of the Civil Service, amongst others, think that GOV.UK is staffed by cool and capable people. That this digital thing might just be a better way of working.

Two

Lee, a delivery manager, helped me by facilitating a recap session with the Explore Personalisation team. We asked ourselves what we‚Äôd learnt in our proto-discovery, to inform what recommendations we‚Äôd make to take the work forward.

Our main finding: ‚Äòpersonalisation‚Äô is a fuzzy, poorly defined term and means different things to different people. The thing pictured in your head is not the same for everyone. Talk about value you‚Äôd like to create, not things you want to build.

But we have come up with some good opportunities worth pursuing in low effort, lean experimental ways. Testing the feasibility of features with something as simple as a button and a user research sign-up form takes minutes and can tell you a lot.

We started writing the blog post and report for this work and I can‚Äôt wait to share that soon. It‚Äôll try to describe what personalisation is, how we‚Äôre already personalising bits of GOV.UK, and what more we could do to personalise interacting with government.

Three

Michael and Bruce did even more digging into Elasticsearch and how it orders results. Some logic around synonyms had been throwing the results, which we didn‚Äôt expect and isn‚Äôt documented as a change by Elasticsearch. The good news is that we‚Äôre getting closer to being able to roll it out to Production fully, probably by Wednesday after we‚Äôve uncovered the results ordering gremlin.

Four

I helped Jon, Head of Product Community, get to grips with publishing things on GitHub. He‚Äôs come up with things you need to do in order to learn and develop as an associate product manager, which he developed with Scott Colfer. The first version is rather good and it‚Äôs published in the open, meaning anyone can make comments and suggest additions or changes.

Five

I settled on some development objectives which I‚Äôll publish and report on in the open. See below. They‚Äôre designed to help me develop my skills in the DDaT Framework. Will report progress next week.

Objectives

  • Contribute to the GDS PM community
  • Partner with delivery manager to run a multidisciplinary team (agile working)
  • Clearly reflect user needs in the deliverables for missions (product ownership)
  • Get the organisation to buy in to the product strategy inc. fellow PMs (strategic ownership)
  • Get in front of users at least once per month (user focus)
  • Realise the financial benefits of a proposed product decision (financial ownership)

Bookmarks

  • Why we created a Platform Health team on GOV.UK, 4 mins
  • At the dawn of GDPR, Nesta warns it is high time for data innovation, not just regulating ‚Äòbusiness as usual‚Äô, 4 mins
  • Public deliberation could help address AI‚Äôs legitimacy problem in 2019, 5 mins

  1. I copied these words from a post on how to make government as a platform real.¬†↩

item.title: The Workshop
item.description:
Light-bulb moments, chats with good people, reading research. All part of this week in my life as a civil servant. Tell you what, I could do with a reset.

Three Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

For what may be the last time during this quarter, I got a few folks on the Explore Personalisation mission together in a room to think about personal data as part of service design and features. We spent about 90 minutes saying ‚ÄòHmm‚Ä¶‚Äô while moving some Post-its around, then drew a diagram on the wall (which is covered in whiteboard paint). It was a funnel with four levels and some words and arrows either side. That was a bit of a light-bulb moment.

It was a great moment because, to be honest, working on this nebulous mission has pushed me to the limits of my craft ‚Äì and at times I‚Äôve doubted I‚Äôm even any good at it. Trying to move a team of highly intelligent people through a sensitive design problem is Rather Hard, especially when they‚Äôre nabbed to work on other, more pressing issues in government.

So hopefully the product of our hard-thinking is valuable and answers a question correctly for the higher-ups. We would have preferred to focus instead on being present for the important task at hand, not sliced up, wafer-thin, and draped across several sandwiches.

Two

Another large portion of the week was spent beginning to craft the narrative to sell our work. That means I poured some words into a slide deck and reviewed the history of GDS, while also tearing apart some poor research (Internet of Things for your benefits history, anyone?) which informs decision-makers. Better polls are available, so the narrative will include those.

Three

We‚Äôre getting mighty close to rolling the Elasticsearch upgrade out to Production, but first we‚Äôre checking whether the upgrade will affect the ordering of search results ‚Äì which it will, though not by much. 80 per cent of the top 1,000 searches return the same link in first place; 60 per cent have the same links in first and second place. The next question to answer is ‚ÄòHow many searches return the same links in the first set of ten results?‚Äô Because as long as a link doesn‚Äôt move more than four or five places, users will likely still be able to find it easily.

Since we‚Äôve spent a while digging in to how weightings and similarity scores work, we‚Äôre rather well placed to work on those next quarter ‚Äì which we‚Äôll have to anyway since indexing changes completely between v5 and v6.

Reflections

What I Learned

That, hooray, I‚Äôm not an imposter! Neither are you, probably. We‚Äôre all making it up as we go along. And so here‚Äôs the best life advice I‚Äôve ever received, for you to remember and act on.

What I Could Do Better

Make my monthly objectives part of my weeknotes. I said before that I‚Äôd do that and I haven‚Äôt. Definitely worse at making lists recently. Need to return to making lists. Self-organisation? Yes, I could be better a self-organisation.

Bookmarks

  • Trust in data is ‚Äònew currency‚Äô for the Co-op, 3 mins
  • The new ecosystem of data trusts, 19 mins
  • Creating a Rebel Network to deliver transformation, 4 mins

item.title: The Key Findings
item.description:
For the first time, I started to see the end of the tunnel for the personalisation mission. That doesn‚Äôt mean we‚Äôve figured it all out, rather that we know it‚Äôll take longer to answer this question ‚Äì but we‚Äôve noticed the first stage. It‚Äôs going to require all my dexterity of character and strategic skills to carry the rest through, so it‚Äôs time to take another step up‚Ä¶probably.

Five Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

Regrouped the Explore Personalisation team to run through the results of our research. It‚Äôs been mainly myself and Paola interviewing people, with the occasional bit of help from Tim and Kate, while Mark has been focussing on the desk research. This session meant everyone was able to spend time writing up the findings from interviews with senior stakeholders and international governments, observing where the research might converge.

We drew out some key themes from the findings and started to think about risks and opportunities. There‚Äôs some tidbits of value in there which need exploring, but many of our assumptions were confirmed.

Two

The product managers got together to review our 2019‚Äì20 roadmap for GOV.UK. It‚Äôs a tough time to be ambitious, what with Brexit and all, so we ranked missions based on immediate priority. If it turns out that Brexit doesn‚Äôt demand too much of our time, we‚Äôll be able to open up some exciting missions.

Three

Allan Donald came in to talk about metadata and content at the BBC. It was hugely enjoyable and I picked up some presentation tips, alongside all the good chatter about semantics, structure and tagging content intelligently.

Four

The Explore Personalisation team grouped again, this time to assess the signals we were seeing in the research. Some scenarios were put together in which a particular feature idea might have been useful. However, we were uncomfortable with the solutionising and the main problem was that all the ideas had such a range of personalisation at play. From simple reminders to consent control, from tailored navigation to fully integrated cross-department data layers, there was a ton to process.

We‚Äôve decided to put together a ‚Äòscale of personalisation‚Äô mapping the value a user might get against the level of personal data they‚Äôd need to hand over. It‚Äôs all theory but should form the basis for some design principles around using personal data. The Data Permissions Catalogue by Projects by IF and the Open Data Institute‚Äôs Data Ethics Canvas have been useful in guiding our thinking.

Five

We had an enjoyable time talking to our Director of Delivery & Support, David Lewis, whose experience in digital transformation is quite impressive. He offered his time as a sounding board for our queries, which I‚Äôd like to take him up on. It was also helpful to speak with Kevin Cunnington, our Director General, this week and hear what he‚Äôs up to on his own frontlines for the organisation.

Reflections

What I Learned

Even the most senior of stakeholders can be approachable, and actually it‚Äôs time to step my game up.

What I Could Do Better

Public speaking and confidence in presentations. I often get butterflies and have a few techniques to deal with those, but I‚Äôd like to do better. I‚Äôve signed up to a public speaking bootcamp at General Assembly.

Bookmarks

  • Unicorns, Ontologies and How the Mind Organizes the World, 5 mins
  • 30 years on, what‚Äôs next #ForTheWeb?, 6 mins
  • Furman Review: Access to data is a new tool against monopoly, 5 mins
  • Making connections, 6 mins
  • ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not leaving this bar until we‚Äôve come up with such a great idea that I can‚Äôt sack you‚Äù, 17 mins
  • Prioritize Opportunities, Not Solutions, 9 mins

item.title: The Threads
item.description:
Four Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

Fascinating chat with Corinne Cordes who worked on Results 10, the New Zealand government‚Äôs early research into government transformation a few years ago. The interesting point was that they felt picking out life events as a solution was midjudged, but then hindsight is 20/20 vision ‚Äì it‚Äôs easy to say that. Mind you, they‚Äôve gone on to look into legislation-as-code which was covered by Apolitical the same day, coincidentally. I‚Äôd like to pick up that thread with them and explore the area more.

I chatted with people from the Netherlands and Germany governments too.

Two

Check-in with the programme team went well, not much to report beyond the fact that no other government provides personalised, customised homepages, etc. One of our key results is to prototype and test our riskiest hypotheses, and they questioned whether there was enough time left to do that. It‚Äôs hard when your team has been taken away and put on other missions, but I don‚Äôt think we can justly arrive at a conclusion without some hard evidence.

Three

We put together a roadmap for upgrading to Elasticsearch (ES) 6 in the near future. EU Exit on 29 March means we‚Äôll possibly not be able to switch over to our new ES 5.6 clusters as soon as we‚Äôd liked, because it‚Äôs better to leave all systems stable and operational that week instead of introducing new complexity to the stack. But it‚Äôs good to have clarity for how long it will likely take us to jump to ES 6 next quarter.

Thinking about continued search performance during the Brexit period raised an old idea to repurpose Search Performance Explorer to ensure that search results rankings persist during the upgrade. We may need to spin up something quickly.

Four

Eventually got the opportunity to present our work on the cache clearing service, front-end resilience and load-testing the publishing pipeline, which we were originally billed to do in October (see S02E02). It seemed to be received well and it was good to show the work we‚Äôd done on securing the operations of the platform for Brexity busy-ness.

Reflections

What I Learned

The registry-up vs services-down models of government transformation come up against issues of siloed departments.

What I Could Do Better

A few strands of work across the programme started to converge in my head this week, but I‚Äôve not given much time towards planning out the work for next quarter to bring those together. I‚Äôll need to prepare before my meeting with Ganesh next week.

Bookmarks

  • For e-government to flourish, policy-making must change, 5 mins
  • The incoherence of ‚Äúevidence-based policy-making‚Äù, 4 mins
  • Inversion and The Power of Avoiding Stupidity, 2 mins
  • ‚ÄúDigital‚Äù Is Not The Only Channel, 3 mins
  • The attention economy is dead, 5 mins

item.title: The Reflection
item.description:
It‚Äôs all coming together. An impromptu beer with Trilly on Monday set me up for a reflective week. So here‚Äôs to the next 12 months!

Four Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

About half the week was spent writing up my performance objectives for the year. This involves setting a deliverable (it‚Äôs an outcome, really), describing the behaviours for how you‚Äôll achieve it, and then relating things you‚Äôve actually done to those behaviours. For example, I wanted to manage and reduce the massive backlog on Platform Health, so I set up points during the week to do that, created a bugs prioritisation framework (with Martin) and actively worked through cards. Each retro we reported the number of bugs and other cards dealt with.

I had various objectives described and met like that.

  • Manage the massive backlog
  • Contribute to the GDS product management community
  • Have a sustainable workload
  • Lead the team on pipeline work
  • Identify opportunities to make GOV.UK healthier
  • Frame problems and set priorities for product work
  • Work in the open
  • And more

You get the picture.

Filling in the sheet was time-consuming but not as laborious as it could have been, thanks to having written weeknotes since July 2018. It was good to reflect on the last 12 months as a whole.

Two

Paola and I spoke to the Estonian government about their state portal, X-Road and the intersection between service provision, legislation, politics and representation. I wondered how they might ensure universal and fair high-quality service delivery for people not part of the digital programme. Apparently 98% of people have access to a computer and the Internet ‚Äì but that doesn‚Äôt mean they can or do use it. It‚Äôs good that they‚Äôre an enabler of GDPR though and people aren‚Äôt limited by needing to apply for things, their citizens can get benefits automatically. They also save 240 working hours every 3 minutes.

I need to speak to Pete H about when he visited Estonia in 2013.

Three

We also chatted to Allan Donald at the BBC about their personalisation of content. As a semantics and metadata fan, it was pretty interesting, but so too were the tales of their content operating model and governance. It has not been without its trials and tribulations. He‚Äôs coming to visit to tell us more about how it works and what problems it solves, which is really good.

Needless to say, research into this space continues but we‚Äôll not draw any conclusions until we‚Äôve heard the voice of users.

Four

After a few back-and-forth messages with HMCTS over the last couple of months, they‚Äôre looking at moving towards publishing in HTML rather than updating 50 PDFs every day. It means they don‚Äôt have to get in touch every time there‚Äôs an anonymity order and their content will be more accessible. The cost to them? ‚ÄòNot much of a problem‚Äô according to one of their people.

This all came about because I spent 15 minutes chatting on the phone after they sent through an urgent support request. 15 minutes spent understanding the nature of their problem, assessing the options together, which gave us chance to deliver a better, long-term solution for all.

Just 15 minutes chatting to another human.

Reflections

What I Learned

That I need to change my weeknotes slightly, so that they feed directly into my performance objectives. Might as well make them work for me.

What I Could Do Better

Spend more time thinking about next quarter. This will help in check-in next week and feed into planning for next quarter too.

Bookmarks

I‚Äôve not been reading as much the past couple of weeks, need to fix that.

  • Internet realism, 4 mins
  • Inside the London tech scene‚Äôs frantic plan to stop Brexit, 7 mins

item.title: The Syndication
item.description:
A bit late getting these out, it was a busy weekend so I didn‚Äôt have time to write my weeknotes. A decent week but, given that we‚Äôre halfway through the quarter, it feels like I‚Äôm running out of time to write a white paper on personalisation. That shouldn‚Äôt feel the case. It‚Äôs not possible to explore ideas fully within a deadline; it‚Äôll end when it ends.

Five Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

Met up with Martin, Head of Service Design, to chat about life events and what‚Äôs going on in digital government internationally. He hooked us up with some useful people in Germany and Estonia, and I shared some work Porism did on life events and circumstances.

I also chatted with Christina, a user researcher at DfE but previously working at HMRC, about work she‚Äôd been involved in called ‚Äòcredential alignment‚Äô. Some research participants expressed frustration that there wasn‚Äôt a link between HMRC services and Companies House services, and it‚Äôs possible there‚Äôs more gaps like that across government.

Two

I started writing a talk for the GDS product management community meet-up about blogging and working in the open. The aim is to encourage more product managers at GDS to blog about their work, either on the official blogs or elsewhere, but I spent all the time talking about the idea behind working in the open. So I‚Äôm not sure how that‚Äôs going to inspire people. It probably sucks.

Please do let me know if you‚Äôd be happy to take a look.

Three

My team-mates on Search Resilience & Performance got the new search-api working in Integration, including queries for other applications, really quickly. They had to switch back to rummager briefly for some priortised testing but it didn‚Äôt disrupt them too much. They spent the time working out how to create a ‚Äòsuper schema‚Äô for document type mapping, which should mean that upgrading from Elasticsearch v5.6 to v6 will be a one-click upgrade. This will also give the new application time to bed down, exposing any issues we might miss by pressing on too quickly.

They also explored using machines with different specifications for the master nodes and data nodes. It‚Äôs actually cheaper doing it that way, which is nice, so it‚Äôll save tax-payers more money in the long-run ‚Äì which is great. Next we‚Äôre testing different sharding options to optimise the latency and resilience of the clusters.

Four

Spent lots of time writing and practising a presentation about our work on GOV.UK for the Digital Centre of Expertise, a meeting of digital marketing and communications professionals from across government. Because I‚Äôm in the early stages of exploring something ‚Äì what I‚Äôm calling a strategic discovery ‚Äì I spent my 5 minutes talking about generative research and innovating on evidenced user needs.

It‚Äôs a bit vague about what we‚Äôve been doing, really, but that‚Äôs the point: I don‚Äôt want anyone to think we‚Äôre committing to any technical solutions before we‚Äôve found a problem to solve. Whilst I‚Äôm arguably in the business of innovation (small ‚Äòi‚Äô), it‚Äôs not my style to indulge in Innovation theatre (big ‚Äòi‚Äô). Dave Rogers wrote a timely post about why hype technology is killing innovation and got the message across much better than I could, I strongly recommend everyone read it.

For the presentation‚Äôs final revision, I came across this part of the Government Transformation Strategy (my highlighting):

We will transform government services and make government itself a digital organisation so that citizens, businesses and other users have a better, more coherent experience when interacting with government services - one that meets the raised expectations set by the many other (non-government) services and tools they use every day.

It made me feel better about what we were exploring, so I went big on selling that vision not the specific technology. It has made it easier to sleep at night and consider how we might frame any eventual user research.

Five

I wrote a post about how we use OKRs and syndicated the content on Medium. It has been doing well on Medium with over 1,000 views since I posted it, but only 11 per cent of traffic has come from Medium itself. The rest has come from a couple of tweets (by others, not me) and posts on news boards (by me).

For me, it‚Äôs proven the worth of leaving Medium to make the web personal again, driving value to your blog not Medium‚Äôs platform. To that end, the Internet idealist in me added a link to my blog‚Äôs RSS feed in the top navigation bar.

Reflections

What I Learned

That some times you need to wield the vision to carry things forward.

What I Could Do Better

I had some strong phrases edited out of my presentation, so I could probably do with learning a bit of diplomacy.

Bookmarks

Still having a crack at writing a newsletter, please do sign up!

  • Medical cannabis is now in the UK, but nobody can get a prescription, 6 mins
  • Roadies vs. Rock Stars, 7 mins
  • Why hype technology is killing innovation, 4 mins

These weeknotes took me 1.5 hours to write on a Monday evening and I added some final tweaks on Tuesday morning.

item.title: How we use OKRs on GOV.UK
item.description:
Objectives and key results (OKRs) is a simple tool to create measurable goals for agile teams. It provides a framework for defining objectives, how teams will achieve those outcomes, and tracking their progress. It‚Äôs a light-touch way of setting goals and focus. It was originally developed by Andy Grove at Intel and has since been adopted by other product organisations such as Google, LinkedIn, Twitter and Uber.

Here‚Äôs how we use OKRs on GOV.UK, the UK government‚Äôs website. Teams are trusted to deliver value for users, and this framework reduces tension between agile delivery professionals and senior management.

What is an objective?

An objective is a bold and qualitative goal that the company or organisation wants to achieve. For example, ‚ÄòPrepare the GOV.UK platform for the scale demands of Brexit‚Äô or ‚ÄòMake it easier for users to start using our product‚Äô. It‚Äôs best that they‚Äôre ambitious, not easy to achieve or audacious in nature; they are not sales targets. These objectives make up your product strategy.1

Objectives are usually set by the CEO or Head of Product and set the direction for the company or programme. Objectives shouldn‚Äôt be dictatorial goals, they should be missions that every team member can buy in to and get behind. Because they‚Äôre ambitious, it‚Äôs not healthy to set deadlines for when a product team should achieve an objective. Since CEOs aren‚Äôt on the frontlines, they can‚Äôt accurately say how long it will take a team to reach a goal.

Objectives may be put on a roadmap and make up part of an organisation‚Äôs strategy for getting nearer to its vision.

What is a key result?

A key result is a tangible and quantitative goal for how a product team will achieve an objective. For example ‚ÄòBenchmark the speed and reliability of the publishing pipeline, improve it by 10%‚Äô or ‚Äò10% of new users will publish a document within 5 days of creating an account‚Äô. There may be one or many key results that contribute towards achieving an objective. It‚Äôs best that they‚Äôre specific, measurable, achievable and realistic, to help a team answer the questions ‚ÄòHow will we reach the objective?‚Äô and ‚ÄòHow will we know when we‚Äôre done?‚Äô

Key results are usually set by the product team which helps them be objective about the scope and prioritisation of their goals. Teams shouldn‚Äôt be beholden to accomplishing a key result by a deadline or by a certain amount; they are not quotas, key deliverables or a list of tasks. Key results are lines in the sand that teams can reach in a healthy way, by not burning out. It‚Äôs possible to change a key result later down the line, and some teams often will as they get closer to understanding the problem. Since teams are on the frontlines, they‚Äôll often be able to set more realistic key results as they mature.

Key results are often made up of lots of little initiatives, epics to be pulled into sprints or a series of experiments to reach a goal.

What do OKRs look like?

We use the OKR template above to set objectives and key results for product teams on GOV.UK. You can copy this open slide deck to use with your team.

How to use OKRs in practice

When a product team starts a new mission, we add the objective to the template. We get together as a team and ask ourselves ‚ÄòWhat does success look like?‚Äô This produces a set discovery and delivery goals2 to be reached, which usually shape our key results. Since the key results have been produced and agreed collectively by every team member, we have a shared view of how we‚Äôll achieve the objective.

Every fortnight a product team will meet with the GOV.UK programme team ‚Äì senior management for the platform ‚Äì and report on how they‚Äôre progressing. It‚Äôs also an opportunity to raise any risks they‚Äôve come across or anything they need from the programme team. Meetings are light-touch and only take 30 minutes. Product teams have more time to spend solving problems, and the programme team can offer help where it‚Äôs needed.

The GOV.UK programme team may take the opportunity to set new objectives each quarter. It‚Äôs sensible to take a temperature check of work underway at regular intervals, in case there are new priorities. This also gives product teams a chance to play back to management their findings from a discovery, which means that some times the objective set is based entirely on the team‚Äôs work.

Reporting confidence and progress

Product teams will report how confident they feel in being able to achieve the objective, and teams will also report their progress in the discovery or delivery threads of their work. It‚Äôs a ‚Äòfinger in the air‚Äô score to give the programme team a sense of how well they‚Äôre progressing. By taking this reading fortnightly, the programme team can see when confidence drops or progress halts, which is an opportunity for them to help the team remove blockers.

It‚Äôs a good idea to check the team‚Äôs confidence during a sprint retrospective. You can work out the team‚Äôs progress by counting how many cards on the sprint board have been done and how many are left to do. It‚Äôs a simple method, and it‚Äôs OK for you to create more cards after some discovery work ‚Äì that‚Äôs agile!

Why use OKRs?

What‚Äôs great about OKRs is that they pull top-down leadership together with bottom-up knowledge workers, giving them a space to communicate and reach a shared vision. They help everyone move together in the right direction, creating alignment between product teams in an organisation. It requires a shift in mindset from outputs to outcomes. Teams can understand how they‚Äôre contributing to the organisation‚Äôs strategy, and leadership can better set realistic short-term goals. Product teams are inspired and empowered to deliver value in interesting ways, and leadership can foster a culture of determination, boldness and psychological safety.

Setting OKRs can expose some discomfort and issues you might not have encountered before. But that‚Äôs a good thing, and working through problems brings people closer together. OKRs are an empowerment technique to give product teams clear problems to solve and the space to solve them.

OKRs are not an instant solution, nor are they designed to create perfect unity. Instead, they give space for leadership to set ambitious goals that teams can buy into, and the framework gives space for product teams to solve problems in creative ways.

Thanks for reading! Don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out with any questions on Twitter or LinkedIn, and let me know if there‚Äôs anything else which would be helpful.

  1. After writing this post, someone reached out to me and asked ‚ÄòWhat if all the objectives are too grand and unattainable?‚Äô to which we found out that their leadership didn‚Äôt have a product strategy. If objectives are not clear or can‚Äôt realistically be worked on, this is a fault of leadership. I‚Äôll write a little more on what to do about that soon.¬†↩

  2. A few people have asked me whether they should set and report key results in the discovery phase for a new product or service, and I‚Äôd say no. Discoveries are projects in which you explore ideas and gather information to help you decide what to deliver. You might have a set of key tasks to do in a discovery, but the only key result is having a better idea for what to do next.¬†↩

item.title: The Shock to the System
item.description:
This episode will be short, as I‚Äôm feeling ill and run down, and I want to go back to bed. Returning to work after a week away teaching product management was a shock to the system. The pace at work is so fast, so full-on, and it was a heavy week of context switching. Time for a rest and short weeknotes as a result, but it was a blinding week ‚Äì very productive.

Five Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

Interviewed the excellent Simon Everest about personalisation. He‚Äôs a real gem. Also had an interview with Jen Allum on the same topic, and she‚Äôs cracking too. Plus I got to meet Emily Ackroyd properly for the first time, and she was just as enlightening on the subject. Suffice it to say that this piece of work is coming together well.

Two

I had coffee on Tuesday morning with fellow weeknoter, Coco. It was great fun and nice to see her again after the weeknotes meet-up in Bristol. We chatted about agile delivery stuff and her new role as a delivery manager, then dived into chatter about weeknotes. I brought up the highlighting thing that people do and she validated some assumptions as to how people use it.

That was fun. More of that, please. Who else fancies morning coffee chats?

Three

We made a big decision and my team-mates on Search Resilience & Performance started building GOV.UK‚Äôs first fully cloud native backend service. It will mean

  • we don‚Äôt need to upgrade Elasticsearch any more
  • we can instead spend that time on feature work, making GOV.UK a more unique experience
  • we save about ¬£100,000 over the next couple of years
  • we can switch to another hosting supplier whenever‚Äôs clever because we‚Äôre using open source

More updates on that as my awesome team proceeds. They‚Äôve done a phenomenal amount in the last 4‚Äì5 weeks.

Four

Went and met Frances at the BBC to chat about personalisation on iPlayer. Wow, that was a useful talk. Also got to nerd out on product stuff: North Star metrics for products and how those tie into the organisation‚Äôs mission and One Metric That Matters. I‚Äôm going to have to return to talk to her about that, I‚Äôve always thought we could do with something similar for GDS. But who knows.

Five

Spoke to Mari in the Finnish government about how they do personalisation. They were surprised that we were asking, because they follow what GDS does in so many areas. So it‚Äôs starting to feel like there‚Äôs some opportunity bubbling up but it‚Äôs not wholly concrete yet. It‚Äôs also going to need some incredible strategic navigation and, hands up, I‚Äôm not amazing at that (yet). So I‚Äôm meeting up with Tom Loosemore, co-founder of GDS, on Monday to steal some of his wisdom.

Reflections

What I Learned

That despite a few weeks doing what felt like nothing, we‚Äôre finally making the right progress. It‚Äôs OK to generative research and it‚Äôs best that you don‚Äôt rush it.

What I Could Do Better

Not working too hard when I‚Äôm feeling ill but, to be honest, I‚Äôm doing that now!

Bookmarks

There‚Äôs a fuller list of things I looked at last week on my newsletter archive, the latest episode was about there being no such thing as government, Big Tech/Brother, and data guardians.

  • On exploring how to be online in radical ways, 16 mins

These weeknotes took me twenty-five minutes to write on a Saturday morning. It usually takes me much longer, but I‚Äôm feeling ill and haven‚Äôt gone into much detail or reflection. I often write these on a Saturday morning though.

item.title: The Birthday
item.description:
This week I celebrated my first anniversary at Government Digital Service. When the days are long and the work is hard, it‚Äôs easy to get dismayed, but that‚Äôs when I pinch myself to remember that I work on the UK government‚Äôs website. Next week I‚Äôm on leave, heading over to General Assembly to teach on their product management course, which is always fun. Means I might have the headspace to write up those blog posts I‚Äôve been meaning to for ages!

Five Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

The first team retro for Search Performance & Resilience went well. We‚Äôre clearly on the right track ‚Äì it was a very positive session ‚Äì and we have made the uncertain more certain early on, but we exposed issues around the dev VM. Our developers have to download a lot of data to emulate www.gov.uk on their virtual machines, which means they often run out of disk space, but this problem is compounded when you‚Äôre having to load large search indexes too. It‚Äôs a programme-wide problem and we‚Äôre not the only team facing this issue, but it is more acute for our developers.

We‚Äôd heard word that Chris had developed a way to take a slice of the data, meaning you needn‚Äôt load everything, but weren‚Äôt entirely sure the scripts existed. He had previously put together mini-environments though and I asked whether we could explore that too.

I asked whether we might be moving too fast, as I didn‚Äôt want us to miss any important details, but everyone thought were moving at a fine speed. This was improved later in the week when meeting the AWS Migration team. They were planning on migrating Rummager, our search API, but have had to focus on other parts of the infrastructure. Our roadmaps align though and they should be ready to help us route traffic from dependencies to the new Search API once it‚Äôs up and running.

And finally I filled in a massive, gigantic spreadsheet charting our costs for search functionality over the next three years. As Liz Sarginson, our deputy director for Technical Operations, said: ‚ÄòProduct managers should know the costs and financial effects of their decisions.‚Äô

Two

We‚Äôre getting a programme-wide roadmap put together, and I shaped how we might improve our product pipeline. Currently we have support tickets lumped in with feedback and feature requests, which means we‚Äôre mixing together the ‚ÄòI want to report a broken thing‚Äô tickets with the ‚ÄòI want to know how to do a thing‚Äô tickets. And the ‚ÄòI want to be able to do a new thing‚Äô tickets get barely any time spent exploring the problem area.

My proposal is to look into our current models for support, ongoing user testing, feedback and triage, aiming to quanitfy the operations and expose the pain points. We need to collect qualitative data on how this has been handled at other organisations and agencies, and I‚Äôve some experience of doing this at NOW TV and Porism. (My pipeline for eCasework was really slick and meant our user retention went up, because user felt like they were being listened to.) We‚Äôre in need of a good knowledge base too, or at least some rules around making sure it‚Äôs updated. Too much of our product knowledge is stored up in people‚Äôs heads, which is not helpful when new people join the programme or move across product areas.

After that, I‚Äôd like to look at how we work more closely with departments and end users, the next layer of the gumball: collecting and validating user needs, lean testing and research models, onsite observation for innovation, guerilla UX testing and other methods for improving our new product development. How do we best become aware of signals from users and ensure we don‚Äôt miss opportunities?

Three

We held the first Product People LDN of 2019. Four people working in agile delivery teams spoke about their experiences working on EU Exit projects, with some excellent highlights. Move user research closer to policy, meaning it‚Äôs shaped based on real user need. Don‚Äôt force an MVP to be ready by a deadline, you‚Äôll almost certainly miss the real and huge opportunities to create efficiences across government. Keep your cool about you and use your agile nous. Focus on purpose in a noisy context.

Thanks to everyone who made it over to Whitechapel, to the speakers for their time, and to my colleagues for helping me hand out passes, direct people to room, etc. It‚Äôs such a good cross-government community!

If you missed out on the event, view the presentations.

Four

We had a playback session for the Explore Personalisation mission. We‚Äôve just started turning over the rocks to find out what‚Äôs beneath, interviewing other organisations, international governments and others to explore this area. Mark starting putting together some excellent desk research on the rise and fall of personalisation on other Web platforms. I pestered people at Facebook, Netflix and elsewhere to talk to us, but no dice so far. I did a little vomit because Facebook refers to itself as ‚Äòthe Internet‚Äôs leading social utility‚Äô.

We‚Äôve lost our delivery manager to EU Exit projects, so I‚Äôll try and keep the ship sailing.

Five

Chatted to Fajer about GOV.UK Registers. I was delighted to hear that she‚Äôd been enthused by meeting folks at the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport and the Department for Transport. It sounds like she can see the opportunities for taking Registers to the next level, helping pin together some of the fabulous efforts the open data community in government is already realising.

Reflections

What I Learned

What it‚Äôs like navigating a team through ambiguity. Exploring a nebulous problem area isn‚Äôt easy, especially when it is ill-defined and not related to goals. But having a wide-enough scope to uncover glimmers of the possible is one of the ways we can innovate (little ‚Äòi‚Äô). Grateful to John for his post reminding me that being at the centre of the tornado is the job.

What I Could Do Better

It took me a couple of hours, split over a few days, to put together the gigantic costs spreadsheet for Search Resilience & Performance. It kept popping up in stand-up, unfinished, so I could perhaps be better at carving out time for large pieces of work like that. Maybe I should have a logbook of how long certain tasks usually take, that‚Äôd be helpful in planning my week.

Bookmarks

Thank you to the people who‚Äôve signed up to my mailing list this week, I‚Äôm really glad to hear people think it‚Äôs a ‚Äògreat collection of stories‚Äô!

  • #abenotes ‚Äî January 25, 2019, 3 mins
  • Weeknotes 2.4: Keep On Keeping On, 4 mins
  • Organising around users, 3 mins
  • The perennial debate about whether your phone is secretly listening to you, explained, 9 mins
  • The attention economy, 5 mins
  • Open Federal Data is Now the Law of the Land, 2 mins
  • Hack Brief: An Astonishing 773 Million Records Exposed in Monster Breach, 4 mins
  • The internet‚Äôs ‚Äòfather‚Äô says it was born with two big flaws, 5 mins
  • Assisted Digital ‚Äì what it is and how to do it well, 4 mins
  • It‚Äôs time to force tech giants to end the digital panoptican, 4 mins
  • How social media makes fascists of us all, 7 mins
  • Whatever Happened to the Semantic Web?, 17 mins
  • Web Standards: The What, The Why, And The How, 26 mins
  • The Art of the User Interview, 15 mins
  • On Bureaucracy, 4 mins
  • Can a reality TV show discourage corruption?, 2 mins
  • Should we measure if a digital service is a good citizen of the web?, 5 mins
  • We are not our users: we should not tell them how to feel, 4 mins
  • The facts about Facebook, 22 mins
  • ‚ÄúBlack Mirror‚Äù isn‚Äôt just predicting the future‚Äîit‚Äôs causing it, 4 mins
  • 15 Things You Should Know About Product Managers, 13 mins

These weeknotes took me two and a half hours to write on a Saturday morning. It always takes me that long, and I often do it on a Saturday morning.

item.title: The Reminder
item.description:
A mammoth set of weeknotes, but ending with a note to enthuse everyone working in civic technology. There was a lot of switching and changing this week, jumping from one team meeting to another, and then into programme-level meetings for our wider strategy. We also had our first check-in meetings so a ton happened this week. On Friday I left work feeling like I hadn‚Äôt achieved everything I needed to, but on reflection it seems OK.

FUN STUFF: I‚Äôve organised a meetup for weeknoters in London, please do come along!

Five Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

Met up with Peter, Head of Performance & Data Analysis on GOV.UK, to chat about metadata, vocabularies, Directgov, the Integrated Public Sector Vocabulary and other things that my time at Porism got me unexpectedly excited about. It came off the back of Kit and Robin‚Äôs post about a data revolution in government, which the seasoned amongst us would recognise as the latest in a long line of calls to action. That‚Äôs not to say it‚Äôs not still needed though, and I‚Äôm keen to think about ways we can show the value of this work, allowing senior stakeholders to put some moolah behind it.

It was nice to find an ally in Peter, one of many people I‚Äôve been pleased to learn has an appreciation for data categorisation schemes.

Two

Held a lean canvas session with Paola, Content Product Lead on GOV.UK. I did my Jared Dunn bit and broke out the business tools. She‚Äôs been thinking about structured data for content on GOV.UK for some time, so I wanted to get her ideas down in a way that would allow us to test the assumptions. We‚Äôre pretty sure that adding structured data to content is a Good Thing, but we need to validate that it is a Good Thing. The lean canvas helps us break down the overall idea into specific tactical areas.

For example, I asked her to start detailing the solution, what the thing was. She came up with four facets of the product: a tool to build and edit concept schemes and vocabularies, a tool to break up content and tag it, a contextual content API, and something else which I can‚Äôt remember. 1 Next I asked her to list the problems that would solve, and we jotted down a heap of ideas. We then worked through the rest of the canvas, finally settling on ‚ÄòRevenue streams‚Äô which I changed to ‚ÄòValue for government‚Äô.

We now have an understanding of what this thing might be, the problems it would solve, how it would solve those problems, the people who‚Äôd use it soonest and later, the cost to research and build this thing, etc. But everything we‚Äôve listed is an assumption. The next step is to validate whether our assumptions are true or not. For example, we assumed that duplicating content was a problem this would solve. We need to dig into this problem area and collect evidence that a) it is a problem, b) it is a problem of unorganised and unfindable content, and b) it is a problem big enough to solve.

Three

Spent a few hours with James, delivery manager on the Explore Personalisation work, drawing up an initial roadmap for the quarter. We broke down everything we needed to learn in order to write a report, what would likely go in to the report, and how we‚Äôd learn what we needed to know. This gave us the bones from which we could set some milestones, which really are essential for a nebulous piece of work like this. It was hugely valuable to get everything out of our heads and onto a sheet we could put in front of the team.

This paid off in the planning session later, as we were able to get the team aligned on the goals and add more detail to the backlog.

Four

Met with people from the Food Standards Agency (FSA) to see their new service to register a food business (currently in private beta) and its overlap with GOV.UK Licensing‚Äôs food business registration. It‚Äôs a better user experience than the journey on GOV.UK, and it ties into local authority backend systems through an API (if needed) which is a huge improvement for councils. They were quick to place blame on us for broken journeys though, which made things more tense than they needed to be.

I wanted to understand how their service would improve on our shortcomings and they explained how the service worked. I identified that the switching cost for councils would be low, as the hand-off to councils was identical to GOV.UK Licensing ‚Äì and improved if a council used the FSA service‚Äôs API. As a result, I suggested we work together to explain this to councils and encourage more to move to the FSA‚Äôs service. The details need to be worked out and journeys for all parties considered, but the main thing is that we make it better for users.

It also gave me an opportunity to pick their brains about open data, which they didn‚Äôt know much about, but I‚Äôm hoping the excellent Lucy Knight and Sian Thomas will extol the virtues to them. Being able to see the number of new food business registrations by LSOA each month (or something) would be really useful, because one day I‚Äôd like to use that to start a food business.

Five

Had fun hosting an Ask Me Anything with John Cutler on Friday, and the other product managers at GDS seemed to enjoy it too. He spoke about tons of stuff. He really is a goldmine of product management skills, techniques and information, and he‚Äôs great at providing analogies for what he‚Äôs describing.

Highlights

Thanks to Martin for writing these up.

  • Be wary of just being reactive to things ‚Äì this is the biggest mistake you can make as a PM.
  • It‚Äôs an anti-pattern to be myopic on things. You can‚Äôt only focus on the detail of a problem area, you must also know its context and the landscape.
  • Get the reality in the room when stakeholders make grand assumptions about solutions, ask them to break down how the outcome could be reached.
  • People nod their head at certain terms but might not share the same understanding. For example, MVP is thrown around at GDS (and the rest of government) but how many people actually understand what it means? Get definitions on a poster and out in the open to spark conversation. 2
  • Helping is a power dynamic ‚Äì be aware of that. In telling someone how to improve their ways of working, you‚Äôre also telling them that what they do now sucks.
  • Present thinking rather than gap thinking is probably better for organisational change. The latter is based on aiming for a massive far-off goal. The former is more about iterating within the present possibility space.
  • If you‚Äôre a new PM on an established product, create a learning backlog for yourself. Get a prioritised set of questions to help you learn about the product and its vision. Pull them into your team‚Äôs backlog so they can answer stuff for you, it builds trust. Be clear on why you‚Äôre asking the questions as well, to help people understand your strategic approach to discovery.
  • Sell the opportunity rather than the intervention.
  • Talk about uncertainty with certainty.
  • Get HiPPOs to frame their idea as a [testable] bet that you‚Äôll hold them accountable to. Then reflect back when you see the outcomes.
  • Start together. Open up the door to the haunted house together. 3

One comment gave everyone in the room a good boost. He said, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre solving some of the hardest problems in the world, you know, you‚Äôre not delivering a burrito by drone ‚Äì that‚Äôs just an optimisation problem! You guys are doing the coolest shit in the world.‚Äô

So it feels like we‚Äôre sailing through a storm near jagged rocks, but we‚Äôre still sailing. We‚Äôre still doing good stuff. Remember that, people.

Reflections

What I Learned

The value of early-stage team roadmaps, even just for a quarter. Getting your initial thoughts out onto a board is really quite valuable, helping you set the structure of nebulous missions. They‚Äôre an excellent artifact to talk over with users, but this was my first time having a proper stab at one with a team. Really thankful tht James persisted with this and got us started on one.

What I Could Do Better

Dealing with challenging statements. It‚Äôs hard not to seem defensive when you‚Äôre explaining the reason for things being crap, but I‚Äôd like to learn how to be better at unpicking difficult people and getting them onside.

Bookmarks

  • Signposting and evidence - Weeknotes S01E01, 4 mins
  • How Retail Changes When Algorithms Curate Everything We Buy, 6 mins
  • The ‚ÄòAmen break‚Äô is the ultimate design pattern, 4 mins
  • We could still prevent 1.5 ÀöC of warming‚Äîbut we almost certainly won‚Äôt, 3 mins
  • ‚ÄúToxic‚Äù behaviors that society has normalized, according to Reddit, 3 mins
  • What Miley Cyrus‚Äô birthday tweet to her hubby has to do with EU‚Äôs upcoming Copyright Reform, 7 mins
  • How Millennials Became The Burnout Generation, 34 mins
  • Weeknotes s01e03 - That Feeling of Exposure, 5 mins
  • DCMS puts digital ID policy team on no-deal Brexit work, 2 mins
  • Brexit-Related Lower House Prices Won‚Äôt Make Property Affordable, 5 mins
  • Your robot needs a passport, 3 mins
  • Clarity and shared direction, 3 mins

  1. Dagnabbit, I forgot to take a photo of the canvas. I‚Äôll do that and update this on Monday.¬†↩

  2. Definitely going to do this.¬†↩

  3. In horror movies, people being split up is the worst thing: they always die. People encountering scary stuff together is manageable.¬†↩

item.title: The Navigation
item.description:
Quarter four, 2018‚Äì19, is launched. Work scoped, backlogs filled, sprints begun. We pace ahead on GOV.UK. It‚Äôs been a really enjoyable week and, despite one blip, pretty easy-going. I‚Äôve had to wrangle my calendar a little and so, in the spirit of being open, feel free to grab some time to chat about anything: during work hours or in the evening.

To everyone heading to UKGovCamp today, I hope you have tons of fun. Sad to be missing out but it‚Äôs my girlfriend‚Äôs birthday and needs must. To all weeknoters, old and new, put your name down if you fancy a weeknotes meet-up in London. And I‚Äôm having a crack at publishing a newsletter, so check the Reading section for details on that.

Four Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

My new team, Search Performance & Resilience, kicked off the quarter! We‚Äôre looking at three specific problems in the problem space: our Elasticsearch is out-of-support and needs upgrading; managing our clusters is costly on time and takes us away from feature work; and knowledge of Elasticsearch is low throughout the programme.

Our small but excellent team started by getting Elasticsearch 5.x and 6.x running on their local machines, importing data and noting the differences. This couldn‚Äôt have been done without the clear and detailed notes that Kat left us before Christmas, so we‚Äôve a card on our backlog to say thanks to her. Having picked out the breaking changes between v2.x, v5.x and v6.x, we‚Äôre working out a plan for jumping to the latter version.

We‚Äôve each acknowledged the blazing fast pace we‚Äôve had this week, it‚Äôs a great feeling getting up to speed on the landscape so quickly. But once we get into the meaty work, I‚Äôll be mindful to mention how we can‚Äôt always move fast. Tricky technical work deserves some thinking space, so metering everyone‚Äôs expectations upfront should hopefully mean no one laments slowing down.

Our main key result: performance and resilience is not degraded.

Two

My other new team, Explore Personalisation, also kicked off the quarter! Our initial meeting provided us with a bunch of questions to answer, to help us work out the unknowns. Getting a feel for the problem space is one of the essential first steps for a product team, so we‚Äôve lots of interviews and desk research lined up. As mentioned before, I‚Äôll not go into too much detail on this work as it‚Äôs sensitive and we‚Äôll be blogging about it (plus publishing our research for others to use).

Product managing this work is important for me because, up until now, I‚Äôve been on a very technical product team at GDS. This is a discovery with myriad possibilities, many loud opinions both in the team and battering us from external stakeholders, and balances vision leadership with the current climate around privacy ethics. My history on Platform Health risks me being pigeonholed as a technical product manager and, whilst I‚Äôm not afraid of getting into that complex work, this is a chance to showcase my other skills.

Three

We pulled out some questions to help us start forming a roadmap for core products. That‚Äôs mostly the applications in the publishing pipeline, authentication, other backends and some cross-product experiences that don‚Äôt sit elsewhere. As GOV.UK continues to scale, taking on more government bodies, publishers and serving more people, it‚Äôs going to need a bit of operationalisation and programme-wide strategy. For example, if our Publishing product group want to start doing fancy new things, we‚Äôll need to guide them based on what‚Äôs possible now and where the overall platform is headed. We need to build up some data, research our colleagues and form a vision for where we‚Äôre headed in the coming weeks ‚Äì that‚Äôs for next week though.

Four

I learned how techniques for dealing with HiPPOs don‚Äôt always work. People whose bread and butter is making demands can‚Äôt be reasoned with during tense moments. This is where knowledge work rubs up against authority bias, where evidence and lean methods lose out to solutionism and senior demands. It‚Äôs bullshit.

Having said that, we are in unprecedented times and who‚Äôs to say that one way is the best to navigate through? It might be the case that features based on little evidence work, though I‚Äôve not seen that happen often. People with a high degree of domain knowledge can often make instinctive decisions that turn out to be successes ‚Äì Steve Jobs was great at this. But it‚Äôs hard to make reasoned, objective decisions in domains where one has very little knowledge of the intricacies and the environment. Strong product teams exist ‚Äòto serve the [users], in ways that meet the needs of the [organisation]‚Äô, as Marty Cagan says in this piece, and they don‚Äôt operate well under ‚Äòcommand and control‚Äô management. So what does work?

Trust.

Reflections

What I Learned

I‚Äôm lucky to be paired with more of our excellent delivery managers this quarter, which has allowed me to experience some new delivery styles and learn a couple of facilitation methods. I‚Äôll cover those in the post I‚Äôve promised about how to kick off agile delivery teams and credit both Lee and James. Here‚Äôs thanks to them for this week!

What I Could Do Better

Calling myself out for snapping in a meeting, which is the first time I‚Äôve done it at GDS. I was angry that our methods aren‚Äôt respected and colleagues were pushed against a wall, but that doesn‚Äôt make it OK. To be honest, almost every single meeting I‚Äôve been in at GDS has been fine, nothing like the heated conversations you read about in other organisations, both public and private. I‚Äôd prefer to keep it that way though, so here‚Äôs to metering my own emotions.

item.title: The New Cross
item.description:
Firebreak week, a time to make things better and get ready for next quarter. The Platform Health sticker arrived too, which was bleeding great. Proud to have played a part in such an important mission of maintenance, glad they‚Äôre continuing on. Expect a post from Martin on why the team was set up.

This week‚Äôs painting is completely unrelated to the week I had. It‚Äôs what it looked like at the end of my road in 1850.

Five Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

Local Links Manager is a tool we use at GOV.UK to maintain and update links to services on local authority websites. It was built quickly and is a good minimum viable product (MVP), but this week it needed a little more refinement work.

We sat down with our Content Support team to take notes on their process, picking out the main pain points and where we could add value. By far the biggest time-hog was local authorities spending up to two months to return a spreadsheet with updated links. That‚Äôs likely because they were sent a CSV with 60,000 rows! So our first improvement was to add a button allowing teams to download broken links for a council. This should mean that councils don‚Äôt need to filter the sheet they‚Äôre sent, it‚Äôs more easily workable.

The next big time-hog was updating links. This is done manually by Content Support amongst all their other work, it can take an entire day if they focus solely on updating links. This could be solved with an import feature, allowing them to upload a CSV of changed links, reducing their time spent on updating links to a couple of minutes. Unfortunately, due to illness, we didn‚Äôt have enough dev time to get this built but I‚Äôm hoping my good friends on Platform Health will consider taking it on ‚Äì it‚Äôs a small card and a big plus for our operations budget.

Local Links Manager is a good example of an MVP needing time to bed down before being iterated. The product was viable, but minimally so, and over the last 18 months of functioning well the areas for improvement became more apparent. It‚Äôs a lesson in giving products time to settle down, in beta and live phases. Once the gleam of newness has dulled, areas to be iterated will naturally appear from the new normal.

Two

Things are looking good for the product community on GOV.UK. We got together with Leanne, Head of Product, to look at how we‚Äôre going to approach the year and a strategy will emerge in the next few weeks. We‚Äôve been encouraged to come up with visions and strategies for our areas of the platform, and to be entrepreneurial in how we seek and justify new opportunities. I found this really invigorating as I‚Äôve got some decent ideas on what could be done, so knowing there‚Äôs time to validate these and present cases for doing the work is really valuable.

Three

Handed the translations work over to Adam, the new associate product manager on Platform Health. He joined GDS three months ago and I‚Äôve been buddying with him since he joined, as he was a Fast Streamer hired as a developer and put into a product role. He‚Äôs been devouring the resources and reading, and I was really impressed by his questions about the translation work and how he handled getting more information from our developers. He‚Äôs gonna do pretty well, I reckon.

Four

I started putting together the objectives for my two missions this quarter: search performance and resilience, and exploring personalisation. I‚Äôve been blessed with a good team on both fronts, and my delivery managers Lee and James both sent over slide decks for our kick-off meetings. I added some background info, details on the problem space and called out our objective on both decks, giving us time during the rest of the session to ask questions, work out what we know, set up an initial backlog and agree some key results as a team.

I did start writing that guide I promised in S02E09 on how to get teams started, but I‚Äôll add what we get up this quarter too.

Five

Met with civic tech legend Paul Downey. He‚Äôs come up with some absolute classics that you‚Äôll recognise: the difference between waterfall and agile, doodles about technology and teams, the discovery of GOV.UK Registers, and the unit of delivery is the team. So he‚Äôs a bit of a celebrity and I was really grateful he took time to chat with me. We spoke about open data (of course), some GOV.UK history, Vannevar Bush and Ted Nelson, and what it‚Äôs like working with senior stakeholders. That last bit was hugely valuable for me ‚Äì probably the most valuable five minutes in recent weeks. If you, dear reader, would like to advise me on how to work well with Big Wigs, please get in touch!

Reflections

What I Learned

This week was the first time I‚Äôve observed the delta of seniority. I was gifted wisdom from someone senior to me, and it was useful. But the teaching I‚Äôve tried to give someone junior to me has, seemingly, paid off in part. I‚Äôve never been a line manager before but would certainly be interested now.

What I Could Do Better

Got a bit meeting-logged on Monday. Too many short meetings that took the entire half an hour, not giving me enough time to work my notes into something sensible. So I could do better at giving myself buffer time between meetings. That‚Äôs hard when people demand your time through Google Calendar and it doesn‚Äôt support buffer time. Maybe there‚Äôs something on Zapier I could use.

Bookmarks

  • The Busier You Are, the More You Need Quiet Time
  • How Space and Time Could Be a Quantum Error-Correcting Code
  • Survive the Future: A Lesson on Megastructures with Glen Small
  • Let‚Äôs Resolve to Create Humane Products in 2019
  • 4 Ways to Control Your Emotions in Tense Moments
  • Being an indie maker in the heavily regulated cannabis industry

item.title: The Limbo Continues
item.description:
We‚Äôre still in the fallow period, but it has been a boon: loose ends tied, histories written, new ships prepared for departure. Writing reviews of 2018 has been popular this week, and I‚Äôve enjoyed reading pieces by new weeknoters. This weekend I‚Äôll try to find the time to have a little retro of these first two series of my weeknotes, make the most of the continuing limbo.

Three Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

As the quarter has already ended and this week demanded nothing urgent (for a change), I spent a day continuing to document the last three months. This consisted of going through the Trello board, picking out the cards related to our OKRs, i.e. not business-as-usual cards to support the platform, and writing up a narrative on Confluence telling future colleagues what we did, why, and what we learned.

I didn‚Äôt rewrite the details of the cards on Confluence, simply linked to the cards, because that would have taken hours. That troubled me because ‚Äì as Jonathan pointed out ‚Äì Trello isn‚Äôt a permanent record of anything. Hopefully it will persist in the immediate future but it‚Äôs certainly time to look at writing product decision records.

Two

Talking to users is an important aspect of good product work, as is talking to your team. This week I spoke with two users ‚Äì a local authority and HM Courts & Tribunals Service (HMCTS) ‚Äì about some issues they‚Äôd had; and Bruce, tech lead on the upcoming search work.

Usually contact with users would be handled over email but it‚Äôs not always an ideal communication channel. I‚Äôve used phone calls in my previous role to quickly catch up with users, it‚Äôs more immediate, and it tends improve our rapport with users.

What‚Äôs more, it‚Äôs a great way to open up your pipeline for new work. Emails can be very direct, whereas verbal conversations cover more ground. For example, I was able to find out how HMCTS use one of our publishing tools, the steps they take, why they use that process and the steps they take in other similar workflows ‚Äì all inside 5 minutes. That meant I was able to address their issue immediately and gather useful context to consider improvements. It‚Äôs not always possible or necessary, granted, but quick contact would help lubricate our support processes.

Having a chat with Bruce to field any questions was great too. When he first requested the meeting, I made sure to pull together everything we‚Äôd already done and make it available to him. He took a read through and said he felt really good about it, as we‚Äôve had much of the work shaped by Kat from Digital Marketplace who‚Äôs upgraded Elasticsearch before. Considering we were rather in the dark three months ago, we‚Äôre in a really strong position now.

Three

I also caught up with Leanne, Head of Product for GOV.UK, about the discovery into personalisation we‚Äôre doing in the upcoming quarter. I‚Äôll not speak about that on my weeknotes as I‚Äôm intending to blog about it regularly. I‚Äôd also like us to publish the research and reports openly.

Reflections

What I Learned

Fail to prepare, prepare to fail, etc. It works. Although perhaps I‚Äôm overestimating the alignment from one meeting.

What I Could Do Better

After pitching my firebreak session, someone raised a challenge and I replied with a stumbled ‚ÄòErrr‚Ä¶‚Äô. I think I should compose myself more during those moments, I‚Äôm afraid I looked shook.

Bookmarks

  • Leadership dimensions: value management
  • GOV.UK‚Äôs firebreak: why and how we spent a month working differently
  • Digital Government Services by the Numbers
  • Things I Don‚Äôt Know as of 2018
  • We Need to Rethink the Product Backlog
  • Good design doesn‚Äôt just happen

item.title: The Fallow Period
item.description:
A short week at work, being only Christmas Eve and one day of The Gooch ‚Äì the bit between Christmas and New Year that‚Äôs a bit empty but definitely has purpose. Spent most of it either wrapping up the quarter or walking in the West Midlands and Wales (1, 2).

Two Things That Happened

We did more things than this (though it was only a 2-day week)

One

As there will be a new associate product manager replacing me on Platform Health, I spent a few hours packaging up a project I‚Äôd made a start on but can‚Äôt continue. Translations on GOV.UK give departments the ability to share information in languages other than English, which due to the platform‚Äôs organic growth isn‚Äôt a function that‚Äôs handled consistently by the various publishing applications. Since we have a few issues with translations to be solved, it‚Äôs worthwhile looking at how we can make it better everywhere rather than fixing bit-part problems.

It‚Äôll be a good first project for them to sink their teeth into, a meaty technical problem ‚Äì allowing them to explore the stack and the idiosyncracies of applications ‚Äì which can be fixed by focusing on delivering value to users. Starting with user needs will mean they can check on whether we‚Äôve delivered enough for users already, as this hasn‚Äôt been looked at holistically before.

Two

I wrote up what we‚Äôd managed to achieve this quarter and it‚Äôs quite a bit. There had been a few headline metrics such as making content appear 10x sooner for users, reducing the publishing queues by 45 per cent and improving publishing latency by 25 per cent. But after digging into our metrics a little more, the improvements haven‚Äôt been wholly consistent and there‚Äôs still a few fluctuations to take account of.

This doesn‚Äôt mean that the team hasn‚Äôt been successful. Though we set ourselves the task of improving the publishing pipeline, we don‚Äôt own it and the actions of other teams have influence on it. We‚Äôve been successful in finding root causes and addressing those through code, but it‚Äôs time to take a look at some principles.

I regret not having been able to set service level objectives (SLOs) for the user experience on GOV.UK. It was my main aim at the beginning of the quarter but holiday and urgent EU Exit projects got in the way. It started off with a prioritisation of Jobs-to-be-Done on GOV.UK and setting SLOs for scheduling publications, but the body of work needs to be completed.

Reflections

What I Learned

You can‚Äôt get precious about the effect of your code on shared infrastructure. It‚Äôs better to be precious about the principles you set for everyone who shares it. One to run past Alex when we next have coffee.

What I Could Do Better

It was a 2-day week, it‚Äôs hard to improve on answering emails and writing up organisation knowledge.

Bookmarks

  • How Much of the Internet Is Fake? Turns Out, a Lot of It, Actually
  • Why the PDF Is Secretly the World‚Äôs Most Important File Format (Spoiler: it‚Äôs not, it‚Äôs just pushed heavily.)
  • The Many Meanings of Open
  • How can we break the Brexit deadlock? Ask ancient Athens
  • This Health Startup Won Big Government Deals‚ÄîBut Inside, Doctors Flagged Problems
  • Fathom Analytics on Heroku

item.title: Reading List Picks of 2018
item.description:
It‚Äôs been a heck of a year. I got to fulfill a teenage dream and start working on an important and much-used website, which got me thinking about product management, people, work and the World Wide Web more than I did last year. Here‚Äôs a bunch of articles and blog posts that piqued my interest throughout 2018.

How to Build a Low-tech Website?

Low-tech Magazine looks at the sustainability of the modern world and its practices. They decided to practice what they preach by making their website run entirely on solar power, using web design techniques to reduce energy consumption and a self-built solar power bank to run it all ‚Äì no data centres and CDNs in sight. Though it occasionally goes offline when there‚Äôs not enough power, the article really got me thinking about the ‚Äòalways on‚Äô nature of the Web and how that‚Äôs quite wasteful.

Read How to Build a Low-tech Website?

The Bullshit Web

In a similar vein to Low-tech Magazine, Nick Heer wrote about the ballooning bullshit of data on the Web and the wastefulness of filling your 17MB/s internet connection with ads. It‚Äôs an essay on what the Web was meant to be, and what it has become; and how the Information Superhighway could benefit from those of us working on it to take more responsibility.

Read The Bullshit Web.

The Cognition Crisis

Waking up and checking your phone. Scrolling through Facebook while the telly‚Äôs on. Notifications causing drivers to kill people. Adam Gazzaley argues that ‚Äòour constant engagement with technology interferes with the pursuit of other behaviors critical for maintaining a healthy mind‚Äô, and it caused me to turn on Do Not Disturb when at work. We have natural animal minds that are being pushed to the edge by the environment we‚Äôve built around them.

Read The Cognition Crisis.

The principles that make me a better product manager

If there‚Äôs one thing that‚Äôs central to the practice of product management, it‚Äôs a set of principles one can call on in any situation. A good principle can keep everyone on course but also help point the way forward in unfamiliar waters. Ross Ferguson left us with seven principles before he was poached by the Canadians, and they‚Äôve really helped me in my first year at Government Digital Service.

Read The principles that make me a better product manager.

Thinking about SLOs

Working out how to maintain and operate a behemoth like GOV.UK was pretty daunting when I joined Platform Health. Adopting a Service Level Objective and thinking about how we manage technical solutions from a users-first perspective has been massively helpful. I‚Äôm really grateful that Emily posted this by Andrew Suffield ‚Äì one-time Site Reliability Engineer at Google ‚Äì and for all her work on spreading SLO thinking at GDS.

Read Thinking about SLOs.

Teams from Scratch ‚Äì Part 1: Psychological Safety

Building a culture where asking questions and admitting gaps in knowledge is OK can be hard, but this piece popped up serendipitously around the time I was doing a lot of thinking on team-building. It turned out that Alex worked at Unruly, an adtech company which shares our office building, and we‚Äôve been meeting for coffee ever since!

Read Teams from Scratch ‚Äì Part 1: Psychological Safety.

How did privacy come to be enshrined as a human right?

In this year of our Lord, 2018, when the General Data Protection Regulation was enshrined in law, no doubt many of us were thinking Why on earth are we going through all this pain? Preparing for GDPR was a huge undertaking, and despite the boring spreadsheets and confusing issues around compliance, I think it‚Äôs largely a Good Thing. This series by Projects by IF traces the history of our right to privacy and the role of regulation.

Read How did privacy come to be enshrined as a human right?.

Microdosing Isn‚Äôt a Shortcut to Professional Success

Being employed in Tech, with working weeks called ‚Äòsprints‚Äô, can often feel like you‚Äôre actually running a race, and open plan offices can dwindle your focus. Some people turn to microdosing ‚Äì taking small amounts of psychoactive drugs ‚Äì to find a balance, but Erica Avey argues that perhaps we should change the way we work, not our biology. This article applies to coffee as much as it does to LSD, in my eyes.

Read Microdosing Isn‚Äôt a Shortcut to Professional Success.

Weeknotes styles

This year I started writing weeknotes, a weekly reflection on my working week, and I‚Äôve found the practice really beneficial. It‚Äôs like a personal retrospective, giving you a chance to package up the week and move on, making improvements. I recommend it to a lot of people I meet, and Sam wrote this piece on the different styles the Web of Weeknotes community uses.

Read Weeknotes styles.

This isn‚Äôt for everyone

What surprised me most when I joined GDS was that many of our products didn‚Äôt have defined user personas. Nor did we say who we wouldn‚Äôt build things for. Not all users are equal. The mindset of building for everyone is helpful in not excluding certain groups, but it can widen the scope of a product too much. The Parliament Data team, and Michael in particular, have been good in acknowledging that.

Read This isn‚Äôt for everyone.

Democratic technical debt

Digital government has surged forth leaving improved services in its wake. But how much of the enhancements are only surface-deep? ‚ÄòIf you don‚Äôt consider what the long term impact of how you build something is, you‚Äôre accruing democratic technical debt,‚Äô author Alex Blandford says. While also positing that terrific idea, Alex also points out that, well, government has been a bit shit at providing the research it has conducted. A few blog posts ain‚Äôt enough.

Read Democratic technical debt.

Building personal resilience (or how to avoid burnout)

This year has been hectic, and it‚Äôs possible for work to become all-consuming if you‚Äôre not careful. What helped me avoid that was to draw a line between my professional and personal lives: I used weeknotes to package up the week, and I used personal time to replenish my mind and soul. Pippa takes a great perspective on how to do that in this post.

Read Building personal resilience (or how to avoid burnout).

Targeted Advertising Is Ruining the Internet and Breaking the World, and We Should Replace Facebook With Personal Websites

In March, I stopped using Facebook to see whether I‚Äôd miss it. It wasn‚Äôt a problem at all, in fact there‚Äôs not a single feature I longed for, so I deleted my account. That‚Äôs mostly been driven by their abysmal record for privacy in recent months and their involvement in the Cambridge Analytica atrocity. I‚Äôve read countless articles on Facebook this year, but these two stand out. One shows us how advertising has been a misplaced driver for social media firms, and the other reminds us how the Web worked before the 2.0 giants took over.

Read Targeted Advertising Is Ruining the Internet and Breaking the World and We Should Replace Facebook With Personal Websites.

This is how we work‚Ä¶give or take

Matt Jukes is a legend of the civic tech space, a dynamo of humble magnificence with a Bristol accent ‚Äì an honest, friendly, earnest kind of bloke. So of course he wrote an open piece on how he works, which caused people from all across the public sector (and others) to write one too. It‚Äôs a fascinating to read.

Read This is how we work‚Ä¶give or take.

Empowered Product Teams

This blog post covers much of Marty Cagan‚Äôs talk when he visited us in September. It‚Äôs a long read but it‚Äôs absolutely essential for organisations scaling up, past the startup mindset. It reminds us that qualities of leadership can be better than management, and that great teams are full of ordinary people.

Read Empowered Product Teams.

item.title: The Winter Solstice
item.description:
Not a bad week to round off 2018, and Winter Solstice is the perfect day to look ahead. I‚Äôm going to be working over Christmas so this series hasn‚Äôt ended yet, but this week was definitely a major milestone. It‚Äôs time to tie off some loose ends and prepare for 2019, as next year will be hectic. Hopefully my weeknotes won‚Äôt suffer as a result but since people who are busier and better than me manage it, I‚Äôll always have them to turn to for advice.

Five Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

I kicked off another new team, although not one that I‚Äôll be managing from day to day. Its mission is to look at another of our key results in Platform Health, a particularly risky one around EU Exit, ensuring that we can handle a spike in departments publishing content concurrently. It‚Äôs a pretty complex space trying to work out the efficiencies of a distributed publishing pipeline of micro-services, but we made a good start.

Steve is Tech Lead which is perfect, as he‚Äôs an excellent full stack developer who has a deep knowledge of www.gov.uk and how it has evolved over time.
