Aside from all that, I was grateful to Joe ‚Äì a senior business analyst looking at KPIs across our programmes ‚Äì for reaching out and asking for more time to chat through something. We‚Äôd left a chance conversation the previous day unfinished and it needed a conclusion; he stepped up and heard me out.

Five

Also, I got a bit sad we hadn‚Äôt been able to achieve a load on the pipeline work. But I was reminded that we have lots on, and there‚Äôs still time left. Thankfully everyone‚Äôs enthused with the work and wants to do more, and I‚Äôm looking forward to forming a final productive push. I‚Äôm getting together with our technical lead and a senior dev on Monday to shape the stories, and we‚Äôll put them in front of the team when there‚Äôs room on the quarterly roadmap.

Reflections

  • Research is good, but some times you won‚Äôt learn anything new
  • We still need a way to look into turning qualitative comments into quantitative metrics
  • Sometimes nature‚Äôs signals are the best alerts to monitor ‚Äì take time for you

What I‚Äôm¬†Reading

  • Google Wants to Kill the URL
  • From data-driven to data-informed: why the distinction matters
  • Rules for Resters
  • Defining an SLO

item.title: The Snorlax
item.description:
Remember in Pok√©mon Red when a giant beast blocked the road ahead? It was sleeping soundly but looked like a terrifying adversary. Your prods and pokes did nothing to rouse it, but still it lay there, blocking the way. To get past it, you had to go on a convoluted journey to beat your sporting rivals, climb atop a tower and eventually be handed a special flute. Then you had the fight the beast.

This week was mostly planning a convoluted journey in a short space of time, and we‚Äôve still got to fight the beast. As a result, this week‚Äôs notes are shorter and less reflective. It was a busy week and I‚Äôm still tired.

Four Things That¬†Happened

We did more things than this

One

I met our new head of data science. They‚Äôre giving a talk at the next product & service manager community meet-up, so we touched base to say hello and for me to offer help (with my ProductBuro hat on). Though the data science community is small, made up of ~6 people parachuted into teams as needed, it‚Äòll help product teams learn more about their world and the problem space.

What‚Äôs important about this talk is it‚Äôll give the community some context: how data scientists work, their tools and processes, the sorts of questions data science can answer. Data science can teach us a lot, but understanding the boundaries of what it can deliver, in what timeframe, is essential. No one wants to be asked to complete a PhD project in 3 months.

Two

And in relation to that, Martin and I JFDI‚Äôd starting a data science course! I‚Äôve been thinking about doing something since early July and Martin wanted to get involved too, so we made a start on the best data science course as according to one data scientist. It‚Äôs a pretty general overview of the tools and techniques, and I‚Äôm excited to play with SQL again, and it‚Äôll be a nice deep-dive into that world. If we end up making a project, I‚Äôll blog about it.

Three

The workshop to help a department with a thorny Brexit thing happened. It went quite well and they‚Äôre happy to get moving. I found it very tiring though ‚Äì four hours leading four people through a sort-of design sprint. Couldn‚Äôt have done it without Elliot‚Äôs tech involvement and Nick‚Äôs delivery management though. Haven‚Äôt really had much chance to step back and think about the consultancy model for ‚Äòselling‚Äô our products into other transformation programmes, but will make a note to do so.

Four

Another Brexit shaped thing swooped in, which actually dominated the week. It‚Äôs a massive milestone in our roadmap (in everyone‚Äôs lives too) and the lack of clarity on what people will need to do come March 2019 is troubling. However, there‚Äôs ways in which we prepare for that and make GOV.UK‚Äôs vision ‚Äì the best place to find government services and information ‚Äì central to how the country will navigate exiting the EU. We spent a good two days looking through a Brexit lens at our propositions for the next six months.

It doesn‚Äôt change our strategy on Platform Health much, we‚Äôre still focused on scaling the platform to meet increased demand. We‚Äôve been viewing everything through a Brexit lens anyway, deprioritising anything which wouldn‚Äôt contribute to meeting its demands.

Reflections

  • Working with other professions is great ‚Äì expand your world
  • Working with data requires ‚Äòa deep appreciation for what is possible and what will soon be possible‚Äô (thanks to Trey Causey for this)
  • Working with other departments is an eye-opener
  • Oh mate, Brexit

What We‚Äôre¬†Cooking

  • Sun-dried tomato & spinach linguine with courgette carpaccio (raw courgette marinated in anchovy oil, chilli, garlic and white wine vinegar)
  • Baba ghanoush, hummus and lemon & parsley freekeh

What I‚Äôm¬†Reading

  • How did privacy come to be enshrined as a human right?
  • A pizza shop used facial recognition in its ads and they‚Äôre pretty sexist
  • Microdosing Isn‚Äôt a Shortcut to Professional Success

item.title: The Unity
item.description:
An overarching feeling on oneness this week. A good team lunch, some get-togethers with good folk, and nice vibes all round really. That‚Äôll continue into the weekend, whether it‚Äôs wandering the South Downs Way or skanking to to a mate‚Äôs jungle set at Carnival. But without further ado, here‚Äôs what I got up to this week.

Five Things That¬†Happened

We did more things than this

One

Procuring funds and commissioning talent takes time. Trying to do it fast is possible, but it‚Äôs a lot of running around. I did a lot of running around, meeting people and typing words, to get some support for one of our products. Should it be easier and quicker? I don‚Äôt know, perhaps not. Should it really involve product managers? Mmm, yeah, definitely. You need that space to mentally and physically commit to sub-contracting work, and understand what it means financially, economically and strategically to have another team pick up that effort. It‚Äôs just that spending 6 hours a day typing into Google Docs is one of the unglamorous but essential parts of the job.

But between that, I spent the other main currency of product management: time in meetings, with 30 minutes alongside my fellows in ProductBuro.

u wot m8? Ah, well, ProductBuro is a council of product managers from across the community at GDS, focussed on organising and delivering sessions for the community. It‚Äôs been happening organically since Ross Ferguson was artfully poached by Canadian Digital Service ‚Äì a highly prized moose head to mount on your product team ‚Äì led by Martin and Chantal Foyer (with assistance from others whom I shamefully forget). The aim is to lead the community from within, provide support across programmes and give the PMs chance to bond, learn from each other, share stories and tips, and spur the community onwards ‚Äì something Ross was incredible at.

I nominated myself along with fellow weeknoter Richard Walker, the ebullient Lauren, and the creative Neil (he named the group). Despite expecting some pomp and ritual, we weren‚Äôt elected to the posts and our good intent was enough, so hopefully we‚Äôll do the community proud. Having said that, it‚Äôs not like we have any special powers, it‚Äôs mostly organising things and giving people chance to learn more, which is quite nice. Anyway, the we‚Äôll see how the first meet-up goes! In the meantime, we need to induct the new PMs into the community.

Two

Part of the quarterly mission structure is defining objectives and key results (OKRs), which we set out for quarter 3. We set a bold, qualitative goal for the end of the quarter and define how we‚Äôll reach that with four to five measurable, tangible key results.

Our team‚Äôs mission at Platform Health is to operate and maintain a stable, scalable and secure platform. It‚Äôs pretty secure and relatively stable, but the stack of technology needs some work making it scalable to current and future demand.

We set that as the objective for next quarter, and we‚Äôll know we‚Äôve achieved it when we‚Äôve

  • moved to the cloud,
  • set and met service level objectives for publishing, and
  • made alerting less noisy and more relevant.

Those key results have KPIs for product (we‚Äôll know we‚Äôre done when we‚Äôve add x amount of value) and delivery (we‚Äôll know we‚Äôre done when we‚Äôve created y concept or thing). Why all that fluff and the weapons-grade acronyms? Because keeping it all in your head is hard, and knowing when you‚Äôve realistically achieved all you could is healthy.

Three

We tried a new thing with our team Show & Tell: lightning talks on what you‚Äôve been working on. It‚Äôs a simple concept. People take 3‚Äì5 minutes sharing their work, whether that‚Äôs a new application, the finer details of a pull request, knowledge or research. Anything really, but mostly to share context: the unit of delivery is the team, so spread knowledge in more detail because stand-ups aren‚Äôt enough. It seemed to go well but we‚Äôll see if there‚Äôs any way we can iterate on it.

I must call myself out for some bad practice though. During a big publishing event later on, I got involved without being asked, and possibly just added extra noise. The team would have found the solution anyway, so my buzzing around was pointless. No one‚Äôs complained about it, it‚Äôs just that I wasn‚Äôt needed, so should have stayed away. An important lesson to learn though.

Lesson learned, I moved on to where my input was needed, in a meeting with the awesome Simon. We‚Äôre going to help a department with a thorny thing, and he was very, very relieved, because now he can think about the rest of their Brexit thornbush. And theirs is fucking massive, to be fair. This work will give me time to think about a consultancy model for ‚Äòselling‚Äô our products into other transformation programmes.

Four

We had another good check-in with the programme team. I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs happening this quarter but most things seem to be working out. We‚Äôre making progress, we‚Äôre confident we can deliver the key results, and we know what‚Äôs coming up. We‚Äôve found our flow maybe.

They provided good challenge though, and that‚Äôs what we want: prompt us to consider the wider impact of our work, and check our thinking.

Five

On Friday I got the chance to visit the Product team at Ordnance Survey. Michael, their strategic product manager, explained what they do, their markets and the arms of the business, and their long term strategy. They‚Äôre a robust team with great product thinking, and though I had no idea what to expect I left seriously impressed. We mused on shared challenges in the product space and, if I‚Äôm quite honest, it would be good to work there once I‚Äôm done with London. Check out Open Zoomstack, their cool mapping app. Really grateful for them hosting us. Thanks, Michael and team!

We were there to talk about data.gov.uk, which I don‚Äôt manage but do have experience in data: open, geospatial, linked and standardised. It was nice to get back into that world, and it turns out that four years listening to Mike Thacker is an exceptional education in its opportunities.

Many people across the open data space are bought into the vision of data.gov.uk and I know Martin, though the odds may feel stacked up against him, is a choice person to lead it onwards. There‚Äôs a community of people doing fabulous work out there, and government can have trust in it. Wouldn‚Äôt mind lending a hand, if I can.

Reflections

  • Togetherness is a quality of life
  • Purpose is your moral imperative, it is the scope of what you are doing and why you are doing it
  • Only sit at the table if you‚Äôre bringing something we all need
  • Trust in communities

What We‚Äôre¬†Cooking

Recipes we made that we liked, either borrowed or invented

  • Peach, Gorgonzola and quinoa salad with sherry vinegar dressing (this one needs work, peppery rocket instead of pea shoots and the peaches need griddling)
  • Veggie goulash

What I‚Äôm¬†Reading

  • The four ways that ex-internet idealists explain where it all went wrong
  • Turbo Island is a ‚Äòspace left over after planning‚Äô - and Bristolians want it back
  • Rise of the Data Product Manager

item.title: The Boost
item.description:
After last week‚Äôs slump, it was good to escape that trough and ascend new heights this week. It‚Äôs a good reminder of the cyclical nature of things, the natural highs and lows, and how being mindful of those gives you opportunity to change tack ‚Äì if needs be. It‚Äôs another benefit of weeknoting, being able to package up a period of time and conclude your thoughts on it, draw a line in the sand and move on.

Five Things That¬†Happened

More than five things happened

One

We had a GOV.UK away day. It was good to hang out with people I‚Äôve not worked with before and there were great presentations from others in GDS, most notably from Alistair Duggin, Head of Accessibility. He‚Äôs put together a set of user profiles for disabilities and impairments to use when designing services and products. It‚Äôs a great resource for people across government and anyone else in service design or tech.

He also covered how we can meet the new regulations for public sector websites‚Äô accessibility, for which the Empathy Lab is hugely effective. Having never used screen readers before or had a visual impairment, it helps you experience the benefits of accessible design on the Web.

We didn‚Äôt do any strategic, future-vision stuff though people were expecting that. With a quarterly mission structure, we‚Äôre updated on where we‚Äôre headed quite regularly, but perhaps people are blind to that. As a PM community we‚Äôre doing lots of roadmapping at the moment, so I‚Äôll plump for that being played back to teams. (I‚Äôd also like to make it open to the public, I just need an affirmative response to an email.)

Two

Each fortnight, the product manager community of GOV.UK gets together to chat strategy, tools of practice, methods, opportunities and more. It helps us all keep aligned with each other and the unit stays abreast of industry developments in product management. This week we explored the Jobs to be Done framework with our User Insights Lead, Imeh Akpan.

It‚Äôs something I‚Äôve found helpful in the past ‚Äì especially when trying to work out what product improvements to make when your backlog‚Äôs beefy ‚Äì but with an entire country to create user personas for, Jobs to be Done helps us better empathise with what a user is trying to achieve on www.gov.uk.

It‚Äôll be exciting to develop this thinking further, especially as we try to fuel the reciprocal relationship between users and government that can happen on the site. It‚Äôll give us opportunities to develop true innovations in democracy both on‚Äì and offline. Most jobs are triggered in the real world, and we‚Äôre thinking more about the end-to-end journey people take.

Three

We did more research into request tracing for the publishing pipeline, and we wrote a blog post about what we‚Äôve done thus far. (Hopefully it‚Äôll be published next week!) But we‚Äôve done a full audit of the tools available, an open standard we can use to reduce switching costs, and worked out how much each tool will cost us as it records HTTP requests across the publishing stack.

QUIZ TIME! How many HTTP requests do applications in the GOV.UK publishing pipeline get each week? Answer: ~109 million.

A boy is taken aback. Much like we were.

Also I caught up with our delivery manager as the first half of the quarter has passed, so we‚Äôre looking ahead to the next. They were really complimentary on some of my work, but they also gave me challenges for making improvements ‚Äì mainly on my outwardly perceived attitude. This sort of criticism is really welcome and I‚Äôm glad they brought it up, as I do have a tendency to be blunt or seem unhappy. But that‚Äôs not fair when you‚Äôre leading a team and people rely on you, so I‚Äôve got to be more mindful of that. After some tough talk, I was shocked but overwhelmingly pleased to be told I‚Äôd been nominated for a bonus!

Two good reality checks in one lunchtime.

Four

Thursday was full of future thinking. Working on backlogs for the platform suite of products, thinking about missions for quarters 3 and 4, and how we can do agency-style work with departments as clients.

We‚Äôre refining our OKR approach to mission work. We set wide objectives for making improvements to the platform, break those down into specific missions to achieve outcomes, and measure the success of those with key results. We also set KPIs against the key results, to measure whether we need to do more or less work on those missions. It‚Äôll bring more experimentation into our product development, which is really exciting and how other contemporary product organisations work.

But this got me thinking about the long-term strategy for GOV.UK and our place in the Semantic Web. The Voice and SEO missions have edged us closer to that, but I‚Äôve started thinking about other ways to slice our data warehouse. GOV.UK is one of many records of the history of government in the UK ‚Äì we need to make it understandable to machines, and build ways for products to be developed on top of its output.

By the way, we‚Äôre looking for developers and senior developers ‚Äì get onboard!

Five

And on Friday I chatted with my line manager about the possibilities of promotion. I‚Äôm working to the levels of competency expected of product managers in our DDaT Framework, but a job needs to be created before I can apply and interview for it. And I shouldn‚Äôt assume I‚Äôd be the best candidate, but I do feel ready. Not sure how it‚Äôll go but I‚Äôve got my fingers crossed!

Also managed to encourage our delivery manager to write about the team culture they‚Äôre fostering, so keep an eye out for that blog. Thinking out loud about their work and blogging was the channel through which I learned about and was attracted to GDS, it‚Äôs sad that it has declined. But hopefully we can cause a ripple of new, more frequent writing to ebb out of our teams‚Äô work.

Reflections

  • This is for everyone, always
  • User journeys are too flat, what they need is context
  • No man is an island
  • The future is exciting ‚Äì and it‚Äôs an honour to nerd out about the Web and have fun at work!

What I‚Äôm¬†Cooking

  • Grilled peach salad with mozzarella, pomegranate molasses & balsamic dressing and Parma ham
  • Hot Punjabi prawn curry
  • Masala chicken breast with pea shoot salad, spiced quinoa and carrot & coriander salad

What I‚Äôm¬†Reading

  • Teams from Scratch ‚Äì Part 1: Psychological Safety
  • Solid: Empowering people through choice
  • How long will the UK stay the world leader in opendata?
  • The Threat of Hylomorphic Design Thinking

item.title: The Farewell
item.description:
This week I was all over the shop mentally. On Friday I had to just bed down in work with headphones on, but all-in-all it‚Äôs been another good week. We lost a good member of the team, but the weeknotes community has proven itself incredible yet again. Happy to say that we even managed to attract someone new to the crew!

Four Things That¬†Happened

More than four things happened

One

Monday and Tuesday were filled with the introduction and basic training days for user research for government services. Though I‚Äôm no stranger to the practice (and have written about what happens when you don‚Äôt do user research), I wanted to see if the context of working in government changed anything.

It turns out it doesn‚Äôt, not by much. User research is such a robust, worthy field of work that you will reap the rewards by taking time to listen to what people need. The core concept is to reduce wasted effort and time by building the right thing, what people need not what they want. The only difference with user research in government is that you can‚Äôt be selective with your user personas: this is for everyone. In the private sector your personas focus around people who‚Äôll drive your revenue, but not so in government.

My only criticism of the course is that I don‚Äôt feel enough time was spent on eliminating bias. During the activities and practice sessions, the research questions were tainted by bias ‚Äì designed to validate assumptions rather than invalidate, leading one to an expected answer ‚Äì and user stories ended up being solutionistic. It‚Äôs no fault of the course leaders, they had lots to cover for an audience relatively new to a complex field, but I‚Äôll pass on the feedback. Bias is one of the more difficult topics, but this article on cognitive biases that affect decisions is gold-dust.

Someone also told the story of how they‚Äôd seen several teams conduct research after delivering a project, as a checkbox exercise to get past the Service Standard. It‚Äôs appalling behaviour and will come back to bite them, as it did me.

Two

Having read how I‚Äôd been wrangling with someone unfamiliar to how we do things at GDS, Ellie offered some advice over lunch. It was really on-the-money and will help me adapt to this person‚Äôs way of thinking. What I really need to do is sell the benefits of our approach to working, but it‚Äôs unfair to do that without hearing theirs and their motivations for joining GDS.

We also spoke about how the organisation is changing, what that means for product management, and the importance of communicating to stakeholders that some times they don‚Äôt know best. Ellie‚Äôs really talented and I‚Äôm glad she was able to spend some time helping me, so I must offer to give some back. And it just went to prove how supportive the weeknotes community can be ‚Äì she even gave me a weeknotes sticker! Thanks, Ellie üòä

Three

We said goodbye to Paul B. His knowledge of our stack is inimitable, but he did an incredible job of passing that on ‚Äì and rewriting heaps of the dev docs. We‚Äôre going to really miss him, he was a stalwart of the tech community.

Four

We had an excellent check-in with the programme team. They‚Äôre pleased with the team‚Äôs work, but most amazingly they‚Äôre open to us descoping some of our objectives. That‚Äôs thanks to my colleague, Martin, who‚Äôs taken the time to see what‚Äôs achievable, what‚Äôs needed, and broken it down into a good strategy. There‚Äôs a lot going on there, so I hope he won‚Äôt mind passing the reins over to me, I‚Äôm happy to pick up more work. (He did it for during GDPR, which was well needed.)

And despite a few worries about team health previously, right now it‚Äôs really good. The team are engaged with their work, they really care about it, and they‚Äôre asking all the right questions during planning. This is no doubt due to our fabulous delivery manager (whom I won‚Äôt name as they‚Äôre not on social media) who has made it their mission to create space us to think, ensure everyone‚Äôs priorities are accounted for, and injects vivacity and enthusiasm into our daily lives (to boot!).

Working with them both these past few months has been a treat and the sort of training you don‚Äôt get most places. I‚Äôm intrigued to know which principles drive their work, the maxims they call on to move through the day. They could help me as I progress, I‚Äôm sure.

Reflections

  • Government transformation is a massive undertaking with many minds to help adapt to new ways of working
  • We‚Äôre really privileged in GOV.UK to have been on the frontline of transformation
  • The weeknotes crewdem is üëå
  • Multidisciplinary working is a treat when it works well
  • Be careful of hubris: communicating your pride to others is an exercise in humility

What I‚Äôm¬†Cooking

  • Kedgeree with smoked haddock and watercress
  • Asparagus, sweet pea and burrata frittata (should have added basil oil to the pea shoot salad)
  • Globe courgette stuffed with spicy rice

What I‚Äôm¬†Reading

  • The 7 Deadly Sins of User Research
  • The Bullshit Web
  • Introducing Data Transfer Project: an open source platform promoting universal data portability
  • Thinking about SLOs

item.title: The Step Up
item.description:
Surprised myself this week by how much I handled it all. Everything feels like it‚Äôs fitting together well, and despite one minor wobbler I held it together. But most importantly, there‚Äôs a sense we‚Äôre making actual progress.

Despite being skint, I bought tickets to MozFest 2018 to find out where the Web is heading. 13-year-old Steve would be very proud.

Five Things That¬†Happened

One

My return flight from Venice on Sunday was delayed by several hours, meaning I didn‚Äôt get in to bed until 3.30 a.m. Took the morning off and rolled in at lunch time. Completely failed to clear my inbox except for a few unimportant messages, but I did manage to catch up on the previous week‚Äôs events.

Unrelated to but alongside a pretty major announcement, I was told about our deteriorating team health ‚Äì both work-induced and general illness. We also talked about how to share good practice or stories of failure in the team, which got us thinking about team culture and leadership from within. I‚Äôve always been a fan of CharlieHR‚Äôs CultureLab and wondered how we might set up our own. If you have any interesting stories from the tech world, dear reader, please do share tales and links with me. First we‚Äôll tinker with retros, and I‚Äôd like to encourage more blogging.

The day ended well, though, with a huddle on the pipeline work. It turns out the team had engaged with the discovery well, but we weren‚Äôt out of the trenches yet. We met to look at options, pick over them, and it raised questions about whether our work would be for short-term gains or long-term scalability.

But it‚Äôs something I‚Äôll need to ponder tomorrow on a better night‚Äôs rest.

Two

A packed Tuesday, a standard for my working week, wherein I failed to reach Inbox Zero again. Tons of meetings happened, and I had to prepare slides for our Show & Tell during lunch, which meant I was pretty pooped when it got to pre-planning. But there‚Äôs a much better sense of where we‚Äôre headed now: we got used to the ebbs and flows of working on a stretched WebOps team last quarter, and planning is less worrisome.

Another boon is having a workstream to call our own. I presented the discovery-esque work we‚Äôd done so far at the Show & Tell, which seemed to go down well. There were murmurs of support from the tech community, its lead architect especially, DataOps, and the team making improvements to the publisher experience were receptive to our creative thinking.

I‚Äôd love for the team to get some feelings of achievement out of the pipeline work this quarter, to be able to say they‚Äôve made serious improvements to the beating heart of GOV.UK, but I‚Äôm reticent to push too hard ‚Äì and we need to consider the long-term effects and scalability of our solutions. It‚Äôs going to need some tact, foresight and comfort with having tough conversations. But first we‚Äôll research all the options on the table. (A good night‚Äôs sleep helped after all, and this album by jazz/hip-hop/dub keyboardist & SE Londoner Joe Armon-Jones is a bonus.)

Three

Wednesday was a day of highlights.

  • Inbox Zero! üéâ
  • A good planning session with the full team! üëå
  • A progressive retro! üÜô
  • Team health is good! üòÅ
  • I ran a retro for the first time, and people were engaged! üòä
  • People sympathise with how much effort our work takes! üòé At least enough to retweet/like this a bunch of times anyway!

It was lovely to bump into Emily at the end of the day and talk #weeknotes, how cathartic the practice can be, and the importance of reflection in a job that moves a million miles an hour. Her prose is much classier than mine, so have a gander.

Four

And Thursday wasn‚Äôt too bad either. We had some wise words from Neil to kick off the day.

Chatting to Elliot about the work he‚Äôd done on request tracing a couple of years ago was really beneficial. He‚Äôd actually got quite far into implementing something useful, but priorities changed and the work was dropped. Later on we searched through our wiki, looked at archived Trello boards, and dredged up old gists and PRs ‚Äì we found all his work, which means we can pick it up again next sprint.

We‚Äôll hit the ground running on the pipeline work, starting from where he left off, heading towards our renewed priorities. I must make sure to record all the thinking and doing from this work, in case someone else needs to run with it in the future.

Five

On the whole, Friday was good apart from one hour meeting with a stakeholder. They‚Äôre relatively new to the organisation but, from what I can tell, also oblivious to government design principles, user research, and any notion that we build with qual/quant data ‚Äì based on real need ‚Äì not just whims and fancies. We do not use our time and the public purse to make ineffectual gains. We use research and data to improve a live product, not bias.

Wrangling this person is incredibly stressful ‚Äì even a fellow senior PM was finding it hard ‚Äì and I had to take a tea break to chill afterwards.

But that was the silver lining. Wont to get stressed, forgetting to take a step back at times, I took a few moments to decompress and move on. And the rest of the afternoon sailed by with jollity and ease. We even got a shout-out on the programme weeknote, which capped off what was, on the whole, one of my best weeks yet.

Reflections

  • You are a human being, not a human doing.
  • Pebbledash presentations lightly with humour ‚Äì it makes it easier.
  • Even ‚Äòboring‚Äô work needs good PR. Be an ambassador for your team.
  • Knowledge management is a good thing, but I don‚Äôt yet do enough.
  • Take a step back before you fall into the maelstrom.

What I‚Äôm¬†Cooking

  • Fabada asturiana (white beans, chorizo & black pudding stew)
  • Pornstar pur√©e (a home-made rip-off of Bomba! XXX)
  • Sonic the Hedgehog chili dogs

Though I‚Äôve always meant to journal my cooking, I never got around to it and it‚Äôs ended up here. Some times I‚Äôll cook nice things, other times it‚Äôll just be comfort classics (which I won‚Äôt record unless they‚Äôre exciting). But if you ever want a recipe for these, ping me ‚Äì and prod me if I forget to send one over.

What I‚Äôm¬†Reading

  • The 6 Types of Product Teams You‚Äôll be Working In
  • Positioning Is the Part of ‚ÄúProduct Market Fit‚Äù You‚Äôre Likely Ignoring
  • The EventHorizon Saga

item.title: The Discovery
item.description:
These weeknotes come to you belatedly, as I was on holiday on Friday and spent the weekend celebrating my 30th with friends. It‚Äôs still a great practice though, helping me tie up the week and reflect on what happened. Makes me wish I‚Äôd been doing it earlier, there‚Äôs so much from building eCasework I could have shared. Thank you to the weeknotes folks for your kind words and encouragement!

Four Things That¬†Happened

One

What started out as a packed day ended up being free; meetings moved around giving me time to think. It‚Äôs important to have that time to process things, to actually do the work of a PM.

In the afternoon we had an incident review ‚Äì a meeting covering the causes and solutions of a technical incident ‚Äì which has given us more reason to work on the publishing pipeline this quarter. As mentioned in my last weeknote, I‚Äôm keen we take on that work, and the consensus in the room was that we needed it now. With a major national event on the horizon, ensuring the pipeline can reliably deliver content is key.

There‚Äôs varying levels of experience in the team and I‚Äôd been planning on holding a mapping session followed by some problem sorting. After that we could implement some request tracking to measure the pipeline, to find out where the bottlenecks were, and then jump into making changes. Tech leads and senior devs thought that my approach was sound and that we needed to build collective understanding ‚Äì it was comforting to hear my thinking validated, in some part. Many in the team know how to tweak things to fix them, but don‚Äôt know why to tweak those things or by how much.

Two

Andy Dudfield, Service Owner at ONS Digital, popped in to chat to the GOV.UK product manager community about the ONS website and how it had been transformed over the last couple of years. I‚Äôd originally invited him in to hear about all the work they‚Äôd been doing on data, to help us think about data.gov.uk, but there were lots of questions from the community about the general website too. It was super pleasing that everyone was so engaged, there was lots of food for thought on the next steps for GOV.UK.

Andy‚Äôs presentation and the work at ONS Digital ‚Äì kicked off by @jukesie‚Äôs work, which Andy was keen to point out ‚Äì gave the PMs corroboration on our thoughts about user personas, DataOps, SEO, the definition of the term open data, and how to engage generalist audiences.

After that we chatted about the campaigns platform and how ONS might use it for the upcoming census. It‚Äôll be good to have their needs shape the product alongside upcoming EU Exit work, to help avoid feature-bloat and keep the platform‚Äôs utility more general.

Three

Thinking about how we define a product‚Äôs success in the public sector can be tough. Programmes and transformation are designed to effect change, but a digital product is propelled by metrics. A Product for Good meetup on defining metrics for social impact provided great insight from the tech for good community.

How can you turn qualitative comments into something you can measure quantitatively?

Matt Kepple from Makerble has done lots of thinking on scaling impact measurement and trying to measure in the short term, where indicators are more attributable to your efforts. He said that changing what people do, think or have are the three types of impact story or behavioural change that you can influence. It touched on thoughts I‚Äôd been having back in February and raised in our 52 Weeks of UX lean coffee about measuring emotional impact. I‚Äôll be able to develop that blog post more now.

Four

On Thursday we set aside two hours to map out the publishing pipeline and its problem space. It was my first time leading a discovery-esque approach to a live ‚Äòproduct‚Äô (arguably the platform is an assembly of products), but it went well. Our experienced developers shared knowledge amongst the team, gaps were filled in by others, and the new team members brought new ideas to the table. Following on from a tech intro the previous week, I was able to qualify my understanding of how it all fits together, which was pleasing.

After that we had a discussion on what problems we‚Äôd been facing and why, and the conclusion was that we can‚Äôt say for certain: we need good metrics to help expose where the bottlenecks lie. Though I had been directing conversation that way to a degree ‚Äì the Build-Measure-Learn loop is central to hypothesis-driven development ‚Äì it was great that Paul, previously the programme‚Äôs tech lead, called for this. We‚Äôll also be able to take a look at work Elliot had done a couple of years back on request tracking, which will not only inform us but could help rebuild trust in the publisher community. ‚ÄòGetting two birds stoned at once,‚Äô as Ricky says.

Excited to see how conversations have developed when I get back from holiday next week.

Reflections

  • Stop making new things. Start making old things work.
  • Reach out and meet people. We have a great community in gov.
  • There‚Äôs other communities you can learn from too!
  • Oh heck, I love this job.

What I‚Äôm¬†Reading

  • Putting users first is not the answer to everything
  • Ten Reasons Not to Measure Impact ‚Äì and What to Do Instead
  • Why you need ‚Äúnever‚Äù in your product roadmap
  • 5 things Nathan Barley taught us about Service Design

What I‚Äôm¬†Cooking

Should have made notes of these, I can‚Äôt remember everything we made. To those of you who asked for the aubergine recipe, I‚Äôll put something together (though it was technically made by my gf!)

  • Texas BBQ chicken with chargrilled sweetcorn rice salad
  • Marinated garlic courgetti with Dijon mustard dressing and rocquefort

item.title: The Reshuffle
item.description:
Reading people‚Äôs weeknotes was one of the main inspirations for me to join the Civil Service. It sounded like an exciting world, and on my first day at GDS I wrote some notes. I just never got around to publishing them‚Ä¶and I didn‚Äôt carry on writing notes. But when Jonathan joined our team a few weeks ago, he encouraged me to give it another go, so here I am.

If you‚Äôd like to learn more about weeknotes, check out this explainer from Sam.

Five Things That¬†Happened

One

We kicked off quarter two with a relatively unchanged team and a refreshed enthusiasm for the coming three months. I combed through our backlog to reprioritise cards and clear some clutter. It was a good start and needs more work, it‚Äôs important we manage the team‚Äôs scope this quarter. Context-switching is not healthy.

Monday‚Äôs news gave us some good perspective on the epics would could take on this quarter. Having already plumped for one option but been met with uncertainty, a later incident review gave us a good steer ‚Äì and straight after that, another change to the machinery of government helped us reshuffle our priorities. There‚Äôs clear value for us to bring which aids stakeholders and end users, whilst building our knowledge of the platform.

Two

Though my job title only says ‚Äòassociate product manager‚Äô, I‚Äôm leading the product thinking on a few workstreams this quarter. To make me a better leader, I‚Äôve set myself some challenges.

  • Be approachable but not constantly interruptible
  • Speak more slowly, and think with purpose
  • Help people spot opportunities

Three

General Assembly, where I did the product management course in 2016, have taken me on as a teaching assistant! üôå This is really exciting for a number of reasons. The TA on my course was helpful in explaining points which the class didn‚Äôt fully understand, and he brought a lot of experience to the table. Our tutor was running his own startup but the TA worked Product in a bank, and it was beneficial to hear stories from that perspective. Can‚Äôt wait to share my experiences from Porism and GDS.

Mainly I‚Äôm grateful to have a little refresher on their current curriculum. It‚Äôs always iterating based on the nature of this ever-evolving practice, and I‚Äôm keen to see how they see the role developing.

Four

Had some good 1-on-1s with the more seasoned members of the team. Kim Scott says that ‚Äòthe hardest part of building trust is inviting people to challenge you‚Äô, but given my relative greenness on the programme, I asked them to provide critical challenge when they felt it necessary.

No one person knows the perfect path for achieving our goals. It‚Äôs why we have a retrospective, to reflect on what happened and how to improve next time.

Five

We‚Äôve started planning our major proactive health epic for the quarter. Since there‚Äôs a range of experiences on the team and the problem space isn‚Äôt super clear, I‚Äôm kicking things off with a discovery to build our knowledge of how applications tie together. We‚Äôll then map out the problem space for the health epic, allowing us to start validating (or invalidating) our riskiest assumptions and making improvements to the behemoth that is GOV.UK.

This is really invigorating as our team can be seen as having a support or WebOps role, when really we own a product that is the beating heart of the website. We‚Äôll be viewing the work through the lens of exiting the EU, when responsiveness will be key to communicating changes to the nation effectively. And though no one jumps at the chance to record metrics, taking a lean approach to product improvement is essential to ensure you‚Äôre working on the right things. Build, measure, learn.

Oh, and someone asked me to make a presentation about the history of the Web and how it works (for non-techies) üòç

Reflections

  1. It was good to take stock and reflect on what we actually do at GOV.UK, what our purpose is
  2. It‚Äôs my job to create more joy and less misery in the team
  3. You‚Äôre never done learning
  4. Humanity is essential to building the so-called soft skills of product management
  5. Evangelism is inspiring and helps propagate trust

What I‚Äôm¬†Reading

  • The Cognition Crisis
  • Making the Shift to Platform Product Management
  • Revenge of the PMO
  • So you want to do more facilitation? ‚Äì (big thank you for the tip on the Post-it¬Æ Plus app!)
  • The principles that make me a better product manager

What I‚Äôm¬†Cooking

  • Smoked herring, Dijon mustard and dill pasta salad
  • Courgette and chilli spaghetti ‚Äì from homegrown courges!
  • Oven-roasted aubergines with sun-dried tomatoes and cheeeeeeese
